characters: CONTINUOUS STEADICAM.INT. STUDY/ HALLWAY/ LIVING ROOM /
INT. PINK BEDROOM. / EXT. FRONT OF HOUSE. NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: Back then, this is years ago, I couldn't afford secrets. I just had chores. With toothbrush in mouth she moves her hair around, tryin one way, then another. INT. DAISY’S HOUSE AUNT’S BEDROOM. DAY Daisy, dressed, on her knees, helps her elderly Aunt pull stockings up over her thick legs.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: As a child, growing up, we had been rich. And then -- well, we weren’t. EXT. DAISY’S HOUSE PORCH. DAY. Daisy comes out onto the porch followed by two Scottie do the screen door slams shut behind her. The dogs start bar at the noise; she ignores them.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: And like most people during the Depression, I now lived each day as it came, no longer expecting anything. She carries an empty milk bottle; with her foot -- she’s this so many times before - she flips open the top lid of white wooden box on the porch. She takes out full milk bottle from the box, replacing it with the empty one. INT. DAISY’S HOUSE KITCHEN. DAY. Daisy stirs a pot of hot cereal on the stove, as she star at the coffee percolating in the little glass bubble on t top of the coffee pot.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: Waiting -- for nothing. The Aunt, at the table, turns a page of a tired-looking, thumbed and old magazine.  INT. DAISY’S HOUSE HALLWAY. DAY. The telephone in the hallway begins to ring; and two Scot dogs suddenly start barking.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: And then... The Aunt looks at Daisy, wondering who that could be? INT. DAISY’S HOUSE HALLWAY. DAY. Daisy answers the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Hello? Yes. What?? (to the yapping dogs) Sh-sh!! Be quiet. (into the phone) Sinus? INT. DAISY’S HOUSE KITCHEN. DAY. Daisy takes the pot off the stove and begins to serve the her mind far away. The dogs are yapping.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (to the dogs) Sh-sh...

dialogues.speaker: AUNT
dialogues.text: (seeing her face) Did someone die?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: No. No one died... INT. DAISY’S BEDROOM. DAY DAISY rifles through clothes on hangers in her closet; sh takes out a dress on a hanger, holds it up, looks it over puts it back, and takes out another.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: I wasn’t the first relative his Mother called that day. Maybe not even the tenth.  INT. DAISY’S HOUSE, STAIRCASE/ LIVING ROOM. DAY. Daisy descends the stairs. She peeks around the corner, and smiles nervously at her Aunt, sitting in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I won’t be long. As Daisy disappears, the Aunt struggles to get herself up out of her chair. EXT. DAISY’S HOUSE PORCH. DAY. A large car is parked in front of the house; an Aide stan by the passenger door, and doffs his hat to Daisy. EXT. DAISY’S HOUSE, CAR. DAY. Once in, Daisy turns back toward the house, sees her Aunt peeking out around the lace curtain in the window. The Aunt nervously ‘waves.’ Daisy smiles nervously, and g a very faint wave back.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: But I was around. The car begins to drive off. INT. CAR. DAY. The car drives down a long tree-lined driveway. Daisy sits in the backseat, her hands nicely folded on he lap. She stares straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: His Mother said he needed someone to take his mind off his work. Why she thought I could do that, I had no idea.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (after a nervous sigh, to the driver) We're fifth -- or sixth cousins. Depends on how you count...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose he’s related to half of everybody up here. (looks at her through the mirror, reaches into his pocket) Cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: No. No, I don’t. Thanks. Aide puts his cigarettes away. She looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: I figured I’d spend the afternoon there, and after having thoroughly bored him to death, go quietly back to my quiet life. EXT. DRIVEWAY. CONTINUOUS. The car pulls up in front of a mansion, Springwood. Other cars and a few military vehicles are parked along the dri A few cars drive off, others are arriving - this seems to a busy place. INT. HALLWAY. DAY. AN AIDE leads Daisy down the hallway which is full of peo working, sitting at make-shift desks, speaking in hushed important-sounding voices. Others are typing ... Aide 3 i speaking on the telephone in French. Daisy has to step ov phone cables that run across the floor. No one pays any attention to her.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: But that’s not what happened. A door opens down the hall and a man comes out with a pie of paper and practically runs down the hall. Daisy has to get out of his way. The Aide leads her by the arm now.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: He's not been feeling well. Sinuses. Daisy nods, she knows this.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Seems to happen every time, the second he comes home. They reach an imposing door, and the Aide knocks, waits, opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Mr. President? The Aide guides Daisy into the study. DAISY is hesitant. INT. STUDY. DAY. FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT sits behind his desk, turned away, deep even profound thought. DAISY enters, and the door is behind her. All the bustle of the hallway is gone. All we hear is the tic of the clock on the mantelpiece. She stands, self-conscious. He continues to concentrate. The warm glow of the desk is him. Lost in some other world, he takes off his glasses, his eyes, a lonely sigh -- unaware that anyone is watchin rare peek into the toll his office takes. She nervously waits for him to notice her. Then she 'coug Franklin swivels his chair around and sees her; at first doesn’t recognize her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Daisy. What a rare treat. I hope my mother didn't force this on you.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: She said everyone else was away.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Did she? She shouldn’t have said that. How nice to see you. How long has it been?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Oh, years. The Dows’ wedding, sir. In Rhinebeck?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Oh, were you there?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Where would you like me to sit?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: There’s tea... I think there’s still tea. Will you..?  She goes and pours tea for herself. Franklin opens a desk drawer, takes out a flask. Before h can pour, he touches his forehead, closes his eyes, reach for his handkerchief and blows his nose -- painfully. Dai watches all of this with interest. He then pours liquor i his tea.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I can do this because my mother's not here. He laughs. She doesn’t believe in sinus medicine... He looks at her, then decides not to offer, and puts the flask back in the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (sips his tea) That’s better. Do you collect stamps, Daisy?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I - don't. He reaches across his desk and picks up a large stamp alb and a magnifying glass.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Come and look at these... She politely goes to the desk, looks for a chair, finds o and brings it to in front of the desk, where Franklin, magnifying glass in hand, has begun looking over his stam He hands her the magnifying glass. Daisy ‘studies’ the stamps through the magnifying glass - there are stamps of rich colors and exotic and distant pl and peoples. She turns the page -- and the stamps on this page are of people of today --General Franco; Josef Stalin; Haile Selassie of Ethiopia; Mussolini of Italy and so forth.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I suppose you’ve met pretty much everyone of these... She looks closely at a stamp of Hitler through the magnif glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not every one. Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: They're -- fascinating. The door opens and a secretary, MISSY, enters without knocking. She carries a file. On seeing Daisy:

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I should have knocked. She sets a paper in front of him. As he signs, Missy brie looks over Daisy who is pretending to look at the stamps.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (As he skims the letter, to Missy, incredulous) I actually wrote this? (Missy just waits, then to Daisy) My cross, Daisy, is that I am too nice. (To Missy) But -- we need the Senator’s vote. Don’t we? Why can’t politicians just be honest? (He smiles at Daisy, then as he signs, explaining Daisy to Missy) My cousin. Missy ‘smiles’ at her, and Daisy smiles back. As she continues to 'study' the stamps, she hears the doo close and Missy leave. Then she notices Franklin looking her. She turns to a page of the album. Franklin leans ove and looks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Those are from Africa. She slowly turns the pages. They say that's the highest waterfall in the world. She turns another page and stops--. Daisy looks at the stamps, then looks at him, smiles. She turns the page and looks at a stamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seriously and proper) I understand Africa can get very hot. She looks at him. She makes him smile.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Very hot, Daisy. When sees him smiling, she likes this -- she’s doing what she’s supposed to be doing. She turns the page. Franklin once again presses his fingers to his forehead - relieving the sinuses. She watches him, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Would you like me to go?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: No. Please. I wouldn’t. Franklin sips his spiked tea, lights a cigarette -- both which make him feel better for a moment, and so he turns attention back to enjoying watching Daisy look at the sta album.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (pointing out a stamp) This one’s pretty. I'd like to go there.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Where is that?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Well. To be honest, I’d like to go almost anywhere. This makes him laugh.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: The President spent a lot of time that spring in Hyde Park-on-Hudson. EXT. DRIVEWAY / FRONT OF HOUSE . DAY. President Roosevelt's motorcade is arriving. A flurry of excitement, as aides hurry out of their cars before they even stopped, and rush to go and set up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Europe there would certainly be another war, one we would be dragged into, whether we liked it or not. Franklin smiles in the passenger seat of a limousine, as Mother and servants come out to greet him.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: Here at home, he said, everyone was just shouting at each other. Daisy stands under a tree, at a distance, watching all th excitement of his arrival.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: So the President spent an awful lot of time that spring in Hyde Park On Hudson. He said -- I helped him forget --. Daisy waves to Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: -- ‘the weight of world’.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDY. DAY
dialogues.text: A microphone is being set up on Franklin's desk by technicians as he looks over a speech. Franklin’s Mother straightens her son’s tie, smooths his hair, fusses with collar -- still taking care of her boy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (a joke to the technicians) Will someone please tell her -- it’s radio? The technicians laugh. Mother keeps fussing.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: His Mother said he’d run the whole country from here if he could. A crowd has formed in the open doorway to listen to his speech.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: But he couldn’t. Not with how things were -- so many people out of work.  10.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Quiet please...

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I think that means you, Mother. INT. KITCHEN. DAY. A radio is on in the kitchen:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (on the radio) But I know many of you have lost your jobs or have seen your friends or members of your families lose their jobs. In the kitchen five or six servants stand, paying rapt attention to the radio broadcast. DAISY’S VO. Everyone scared. No one knowing what was going to happen. INT. HALLWAY. DAY. We move out of the kitchen and through the living room wh military men sit listening to a large radio.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (on the radio) and I do not propose that the Government shall pretend not to see these things. INT. LIVING ROOM / STUDY. DAY. We move down the hallway and Franklin’s voice on the radi gets fainter and fainter until we reach a group of staff servants in the study’s doorway and through these craning necks and bobbing heads we see Franklin giving the chat i the microphone:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: But I conceive the first duty of government is to protect the economic welfare of all the people in all sections and in all groups...  11.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: And everyone looking to him. Daisy sits in a corner arm chair, magnifying glass in han looking at stamps, while listening to Franklin make his broadcast.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LAWN. DAY
dialogues.text: In front of the house, the President sits in a chair on t steps as a local German-American brass band (lederhosen, etc.) under a banner ("Hyde Park German-American Friendsh Society”) plays for him.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: And even here he couldn’t get completely away. They all wanted something from him. The local labor union, the Hyde Park Chamber of Commerce, the German-American Friendship Band. He catches sight of Daisy in the crowd of servants and st watching the band from the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: And all he wanted -- was to relax. He smiles, and winks at her. INT. FRANKLIN'S CAR. DAY. Franklin drives. He pushes a button on a small contraptio and a lit cigarette appears as if by magic. Daisy is with him in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: That spring I learned to smoke. Daisy takes the lit cigarette out of the contraption; sta to hand it to Franklin, but impulsively takes a puff firs herself, then smiling, she gives the cigarette to him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUNTRY ROAD. DAY
dialogues.text: Another day. They drive down a country road through a woo where trees are being lumbered. Following behind them is State Trooper car.  12.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: Each time he came home, he’d telephone and ask: Daisy where would you like to go today? And I would always answer -- ‘anywhere.’

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HILLY ROAD. DAY
dialogues.text: Another day. The car climbs the hill with the police car right behind.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: His wife, he said, didn’t like to take drives. I learned the names of birds and trees I’d seen my whole life. We drove along country roads, up hills, through woods, through fields.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FIELD. DAY
dialogues.text: The two cars drive through a field.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: He'd had the car built so it could be driven with just the hands.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FRANKLIN'S CAR. DAY
dialogues.text: Franklin brakes with his hands, then, using only his hand accelerates. Daisy in the front seat watches his hands closely. Then she turns and looks back at the police car behind.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: A Police Car always followed just behind.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUNTRY ROAD. DAY
dialogues.text: A Police Car follows Franklin's car.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: That is, until one day...  13.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FRANKLIN'S CAR. DAY
dialogues.text: Franklin drives the car up a very bumpy road. Franklin ha his left arm out the window, and with his left hand he is gesturing behind him -- waving the police escort away. Da doesn’t see this. Daisy turns and looks back, where she sees the police car pulling off the road and turning around. She turns back to Franklin as he drives.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Where’s the police car going? EXT. BUMPY PATH. DAY. Franklin maneuvers the car up a steep dirt road in the wo The car shakes from the bumps.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Oh, they don't follow all the time. Sometimes they have to go and catch a crook or something, I suppose. He laughs. Daisy laughs. The car continues up through the woods and comes to a slo stop on the hillside overlooking the valley.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FRANKLIN'S CAR. DAY
dialogues.text: Franklin turns off the engine. For a moment there is only sound of the birds and the wind.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: What a lovely spot. We've not been here before.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: No. I've been saving this.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: What a beautiful view. As she looks off, he leans over and turns on the car radi

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I like this song.  14. As the song plays, Franklin smiles one of his big smiles Daisy, then dispenses a lit cigarette from the little machine. He puffs. The cigarette smoke curls out of the c as they listen. Daisy is lost in the song, in the view, in the swirling s she hums along with the song. Then she notices that Frank looking at her; he takes her hand in his. He her puts her on his thigh. And leaves it there. Daisy looks down at her hand on Franklin’s thigh. She loo him, looking out the window, smoking. He takes her hand, and puts it on his groin. She hesitates, then begins to unbutton his trousers; chec see if he objects or if this is what he wants. He just looks off, smoking. Then without looking, he help unbuckling his belt. From the perspective of the backseat, it soon becomes cle she is rubbing him, masturbating him. He closes his eyes, bites his lip, as he looks off into t woods. And after a moment of this, it is clear that he comes. Pa Daisy doesn’t know what to do. She looks at him; he begin button up his trousers, buckle his belt. She looks away into the woods, not sure whether to be embarrassed or not. Franklin finishes buttoning and tries to hand her his poc handkerchief. She doesn’t notice at first; her mind racin He touches her knee, which startles her; she sees the off handkerchief, and takes it.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I’m sorry. I’m--

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I’m the one who should apologize... With his handkerchief, she begins to wipe her dress and h hands.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Should we go back?  15. Daisy nods, as she wipes.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: I knew, even without him saying anything that we were now -- not just fifth cousins -- but very good friends. He turns off the car radio and a telephone rings. INT. DAISY’S HOUSE HALLWAY/ KITCHEN. DAY. Daisy is on the telephone, giggling like a schoolgirl, unconsciously playing her hair, smiling, transfixed by th conversation.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) As soon as I can get away. (She laughs.) She hangs up and as she fixes her hair she goes into the kitchen. The moment she enters the kitchen, she stops preening. He her Aunt sits at the table; a good-sized lunch finished i front of her. Daisy starts to pick up her Aunt’s dishes a take them to the sink.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: The President wishes to see me. (and this answers everything) And he’s the President. Aunt looks at her. Daisy begins to wash the dishes.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: He wishes to show me a new -- stamp. Daisy washes a pot. EXT. DAISY’S HOUSE PORCH. DAY. DAISY runs out of the door, the screen door slamming behi and she hurries into her own car and begins to drive off.  19 16.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: And so time passed. Time measured now in Franklin’s visits home. INT. FRANKLIN'S CAR. DAY. Franklin's car as he drives it back up a very narrow, ste bumpy road. Daisy is at his side. She looks back. They ar alone.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Look at that -- the police have left us alone yet again. EXT. A HILLSIDE. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: They seem to have a sixth sense about that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: They do, don't they? EXT. DIRT ROAD. DAY. The car comes up a steep incline, it is shaking and bounc through ruts, and over rocks. Daisy looks at Franklin, smiles, as she bounces, holding He reaches down and puts the car into first gear and driv little farther up. The road gets even narrower, trees lim bang against the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Where are we going? EXT. TOP COTTAGE. DAY. And there, suddenly revealed, hidden from the road is a_ stone cottage. She looks at him, confused: what is this? He stops the car, and turns off the engine.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: It’s lovely. They sit in the car looking at the cottage.  17.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I had it built. It's where I’1l retire. I’1ll write those detective books I'm always talking about. She looks at him and nods.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Go look around. She gets out of the car, and goes toward the house; she c believe her eyes. Franklin's car door opens and first one and then the seco leg are lifted out, held tight by leg braces. EXT. TOP COTTAGE. DAY. Daisy runs excitedly through the cottage, opens the slidi glass doors and bursts out onto the porch.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: It’s heaven!! Franklin has made it to the porch. He looks off across th valley:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I have been thinking, Daisy... He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: What? (no response) What have you been thinking?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: That I.. I’d like to--. To share with you -- this. She stands across the porch from him, watching him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: When I have to be away...You know I have to be away. He turns to her, she nods.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Should you ever miss me...? She looks at him.  18.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: You think you might miss me? She smiles -- of course she will.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (teasing her) Well, if you ever do --

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Do you ever miss me? He looks at her, then:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I always do. (about the house) A place to come. And be alone. (he smiles at her) And miss me... She looks at him lovingly. Franklin just smiles. She clumsily hugs him, which nearly knocks him over; she grabs him as he totters; he just keeps smiling at her.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY/ KITCHEN. DAY
dialogues.text: Daisy, in Franklin’s study, pulls out a drawer of the des fumbles through some papers, and takes out a small bottle aspirin.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: By now everyone was used to me. I was the cousin who’s always visiting. No one ever even asked me why that was. She opens the door to the Living Room where she finds Franklin's Mother, with Tommy QUALTERS, a copy of Scribne magazine in her hand. Around them, staff are cleaning and moving furniture, flowers, etc.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Has he read this?  19.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: I believe he has.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (reading from the magazine, as she moves toward the Hallway with Daisy and Qualters) "If one could choose, from all possible British personalities, the two who might make the best impression upon Americans -- King George and Queen Elizabeth would not even make the short list." (She looks up, outraged) How dare they talk about Royalty like this! The Hallway is packed and buzzing with tides of servants tradesmen carrying flowers and various packages. Everyone seems busy and in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: No King of England had ever visited America before. But now he was coming -- to Hyde Park on Hudson. We move off, following Maid 2 who hurries towards the Kit clutching a large vase, taking us into the ‘backstage’ ar of the house which is also teeming with activity. Maid 2 almost collides with Maid 1 who is rushing towards the Di Room. We follow Maid 1 who nervously approaches Mother, w by now has reached the Dining Room.

dialogues.speaker: MAID 1
dialogues.text: Mrs Roosevelt, we appear not to have enough plates.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: What??

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: Franklin warned us, today, stay out of Mother’s way.

dialogues.speaker: MAID 1
dialogues.text: We don't have enough plates. Someone miscounted.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: You tell me this now? Mother's English Butler now hurries in.  20.

dialogues.speaker: BUTLER
dialogues.text: Mrs Astor has called again.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Mrs Astor. She'll have plates. We'll borrow hers. (Mother starts to head off towards the Kitchen) On second thought -- we’ll ask her cook. Mrs Astor is so rich, she doesn’t know what she has. The Butler hesitates -- this is all too much for him -- t he straightens his coat and we follow him as he heads off into the Hallway, where two black servants, Nelson and Thomas, have entered from outside, carrying their bags, a dressed in their travel clothes. The Butler stops and stares at them.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: (to the Butler) Good morning. The Butler looks them up and down.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Could you tell us which way’s the kitchen? The Butler ignores their question and heads off at speed towards the Kitchen to protest their presence. We follow the Butler into the Kitchen where there is a chaotic scene of preparation for that evening’s dinner. Dishes being prepared, vegetables cut, pots boiling, with cooks and cooks’ helpers working at double-speed. Mother is inspecting a vast and ornate dessert. A female stands next to her, waiting for the verdict.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Good. Good. But is ‘good’ the best we can do? They are royalty. Maid 1 is holding the kitchen telephone. With her hand ov the receiver, she calls to Mother:

dialogues.speaker: MAID 1
dialogues.text: We can borrow the plates, ma’am!

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Thank God for rich neighbors.  21. Maid 2 appears out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (to Maid 2) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MAID 2
dialogues.text: Their rooms are ready, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (she heads off to check on their rooms) ) The poor dears are going to be exhausted. Daisy stands at the sink, she takes a water glass off of shelf, and turns on the tap.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: (wiping the perspiration from her brow, to a Scullery Maid) ‘Poor dears.’

dialogues.speaker: MAID 2
dialogues.text: Exhausted my arse.

dialogues.speaker: BUTLER
dialogues.text: I'd watch what I said, if I were you. The Butler follows Mother out of the Kitchen. Maid 2 sticks her tongue out at the departed Butler. The Cook then clears her throat and gestures to Maid 2, t Daisy is standing right there. Maid 2 then turns to Daisy, and smiles. Daisy, filling th glass at the sink, ‘smiles’ back and then leaves via the door towards the Lawn.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: The only quiet place left to work was outside. EXT. LAWN. DAY. Daisy, water glass and pill bottle in hand, heads across lawn toward Franklin and Missy who sit together at a heal distance from all of the chaos of the house.  22. Piles of papers and files surround Franklin who is just finishing the article in the magazine as Daisy reaches th phone on a very long lead is on the ground next to him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Missy, have you seen this?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Scribner's? Not this month. He hands her the magazine to read.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (seeing the glass and pills) What are those for?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: He has a headache.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (to Franklin) You do?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: His sinuses again. Happens this time every year.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: I know that. Daisy hands Franklin the glass and a couple of aspirin.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (to Franklin) You didn’t say anything about a headache.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: He's not going to trouble you with everything, Missy. You have enough on your plate.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: What does that mean? Aide 2 has brought Franklin a few messages, which he open and reads as:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: It means -- you take very good care of me, Missy. (then) I mean you both do. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: mM.  23. FRANKLIN (cont'd) (to the Aide, about the message) I‘1ll call in the morning. They -- can wait. Can’t they?

dialogues.speaker: AIDE 2
dialogues.text: They can, sir. Aide 2 heads back as Qualters now reaches them, having crossed the lawn from the house.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: They have left New York. Estimated time of arrival: 6pm.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Good. Both Daisy and Missy are listening now.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: The State Police are predicting crowds of up to three hundred thousand along their route here.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (to Franklin) You're smiling.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I am. It means a lot -- that they’re welcomed. It says something.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: I thought you'd appreciate that, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (to Franklin) And what does it say?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: That maybe, Daisy, their visit will be a success. And that is very important. He suddenly looks at her and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: To show the whole world that we are the best of friends. Qualters has started to head back, stops.  24.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: And in each town, as the Royals drive through, we're ringing church bells.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Excellent. (then shouts to him as he goes) Set up the drinks tray in the library. Qualters hearing this looks pained.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Is this something you've addressed with your mother?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I'm trying not to address it with my mother, which is why I'm asking him to do it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. AN UPSTAIRS BATHROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: A PLUMBER is on his knees installing a new toilet seat. Franklin's MOTHER stands over him watching everything he does. He finishes the last screw, looks to Mother:

dialogues.speaker: PLUMBER
dialogues.text: Real rosewood. Still got the smell.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Is that why it cost so much? He smells the toilet seat. Rubs his hand around it -- sho off its smoothness. A couple of Maids stand in the doorway watching, as Mothe hesitates then leans down and opens and closes the seat a times to test it out.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDY. DAY
dialogues.text: Qualters is setting up a drinks tray. The door is open and a severe looking woman, Eleanor, sto in the doorway. She just looks at what is being set up.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: I’m just doing what I’m told.  25. We notice MAID 1 in the corner cleaning the curtains. The look at her, and she hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (about the Maid leaving and the drinks tray) So much for your little secret... INT. LIVING ROOM. DAY. Eleanor comes out of the study and heads down the hallway only to pass Franklin’s Mother, who is furious, on her wa the study, MAID 1 right behind her. Mother and Eleanor look at each other:

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Good morning. Mother reaches the study door, and goes in without knocki

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: We are not going to serve the King of England - a cocktail!! The Maid, seeing Eleanor listening, closes the door to th study.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LAWN. DAY
dialogues.text: Missy continues to read the magazine. Franklin is finishi correcting a speech.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (to Aide 1) Mike, read this over the phone to Harry. If he thinks it sounds all right have him hand it personally to the Speaker.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE 1
dialogues.text: I will, sir. He hands him the speech. Missy looks to Daisy who is lost in thought, and just sta at Franklin. Eleanor joins them with a tray of coffee.  26.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Who'd like coffee? (to Franklin, as she pours coffee) Your Mother has now told me for the tenth time -- not to call her Royal Highness -- Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: She’s told me that too. (turns to Daisy) Daisy? Daisy? Hello? Anyone home in there?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (coming to) What?? Oh yes. She told me that too.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (to Franklin) I told her who did she think I was?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (to Eleanor) I think she knows.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (to Daisy) You're just staring at the President.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I’m not. I wasn’t. (to Missy) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Eleanor’s just brought out fresh coffee. She was asking if you'd like any. She’s staring again.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: What?? I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: She's blushing. Leave her alone, Missy. My husband lives for the adoring eyes of young women. We all know this. She smiles.  27.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (‘joking’) Let’s change the subject, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me you’re embarrassed. That day, I would like to see.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I didn’t say I was embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Daisy’s blushing again. Daisy is very lost now, and as she looks from one to the other.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What is she thinking? What’s going on in that mind?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: What are they doing? He has looked off and we see what he is seeing: three lar tractors with mowers attached are idling in a row across lawn.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE 2
dialogues.text: They've been told to mow. They’re waiting for you to move.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Why didn’t someone tell me this? Were they just going to sit there? They start picking things up. Daisy stands and starts to Franklin. As they head off:

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (new subject, to Franklin) Hick called. For this morning's Royal visit to the World's Fair -- you won't believe this -- she'd been ordered to produce five thousand children overnight.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: What? Why?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: As buffers for holding back the crowds.  28.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Children. She couldn't believe it. Police said that's what they'd done in Washington and Canada. Put the kids between the King and Queen and the crowds. The Girl Scouts refused outright--.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Good for them.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: They said their girls had taken an awful beating in DC! Laughter from the group as they get set to head off.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: So she finally got some Boy Scouts! More laughter.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: But when they were pushed, they pushed back! Started something like ten fist fights!

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Poor Hick.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: When she finally got back to her office, she kicked off her shoes, opened her window and shouted out: ‘God damn the King and Queen!” All laughing hard.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Maybe we'll be saying the same thing tomorrow! More laughing. Daisy, 'laughing', watches Eleanor laugh w abandon.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: ‘Hick’ was short for Lorena Hickock. One of those friends of Eleanor’s Franklin called - -- ‘she men.’  29. Eleanor pushes Franklin in his wheelchair across the lawn Daisy follows, watching Eleanor:

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: People said their marriage was troubled and unhappy. That they lived mostly separate lives. Daisy watches Franklin reach and pat Eleanor’s hand as sh pushes him.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: But I never saw that. That’s now how they seemed when they were together. Eleanor has said something that has made Franklin laugh again. They clearly know how to make each other laugh. INT. STABLE. DAY. Missy and Eleanor now sit together, and drink the coffee Eleanor brought. It's dark inside, with shafts of light through the cracks in the wood. Daisy is with the women, she keeps looking over at Franklin who sits alone, a sing light bulb on overhead as he continues to work on papers. Aide stands with him. Missy is still reading the magazine:

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (reads from article) "A large part of the country still believes that Edward, Duke of Windsor, is the rightful owner of the British throne --

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: “Thrones?’ ‘Kings and Dukes.’ It all sounds like the Middle Ages. There is a knock on the door. They women look at each oth is it Mrs. Roosevelt looking for them?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (without looking up) Is it my mother?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: See who it is, Daisy. Daisy goes and peeks through the crack.  30.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (back to Franklin) Tommy . Franklin nods, and Daisy opens the door and Qualters snea in, Daisy closing the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (still reading the article, having looked up) A very chastened-looking Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: As he should be. He was on his way to set up a drinks tray in the library.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (to Franklin) Did you tell him to do that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I did not and Missy is my witness. Qualters stands next to Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: Mind if I sit in here with you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Gotten a little warm inside? He sits on a nearby bench.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: Your mother -- well, she’s very much in control. The women listen to this.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (as he works) What’s all this I hear about a drinks tray? Qualters looks to Eleanor, then:  31.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: I’ve been told that my idea of setting one out was not a very considered one... EXT. STABLE. DAY. Aide 1 is running a phone line from the house to the stab Other Aides now come in and out of the door. INT. STABLE. DAY. Inside the stables, it’s become almost an office; there a the papers and files that had been with Franklin on the l

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (as he works) I was told this King didn’t even want the job. Franklin's engagement gets the women’s attention.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I’m told he’s -- quiet. Even a little -- shy. Franklin rubs his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: We must remind ourselves that these kings and queens or whatever-- are no better than us. They’re just people.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I read that in your column, Eleanor. He is rubbing his eyes again.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Are you all right? You look in pain.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (to Eleanor, explaining, as she continues to ‘read’ the magazine) He has a sinus infection.  32.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: He gets them -- this time of year.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: He often gets them around this time of year.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (with irony which Daisy doesn’t catch) Oh does he? I didn’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I took an aspirin. Aide 1 running the phone line enters.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE 1
dialogues.text: They just left Beacon.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: So it won’t be too long. He looks at the women.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (continuing with Eleanor) And -- Eleanor, we must also remind ourselves that they are also our guests; and deserve to be treated with the utmost dignity and respect.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIMOUSINE. DAY
dialogues.text: Outside the car, through closed windows, the sounds of ch bells tolling and cheering crowds.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: And all the while the King and Queen were getting closer. BERTIE, THE KING OF ENGLAND, is bent over in the backseat hiding from the crowds and starving; he is trying to unobtrusively look through a bag on the car floor.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: It appears there is also potato salad. Bertie continues to rummage in the bags on the floor look to see what food has been packed for him.  33. ELIZABETH, THE QUEEN OF ENGLAND, is sitting next to her husband in the backseat. Elizabeth is just finishing read the Scribner's magazine article.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Will you sit up. What are you doing down there?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I'm starving. There’s only a rather odd cheese. The bread has funny little seeds. I’m still picking them out. He takes another bite of potato salad and then, mouth ful and chewing, he turns and looks out the window and smiles with mouth closed, as he waves to the crowds. The cheering and the bell tolling continues.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Who re-re-reads this magazine anyway? And where did we get it? He leans forward and speaks to an Embassy Official CAMERO who is in the front passenger seat. Who gave it to me?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I don't know, sir. Someone at the University, I suspect.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: It is you-your job--!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Listen to this.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Elizabeth--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (she reads from Scribner's) "Queen Elizabeth... too plump of figure..."

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Oh god. Elizabeth is close to tears.  34.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Don't cry, dear. Please don't.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I wouldn't give them the satisfaction. They wave royally. INT. STABLE. DAY. Eleanor is reading the article and trying not to laugh. An Aide has entered with a tray of sandwiches and a pitch of lemonade. As Missy and Eleanor choose sandwiches. Dais still soothes the horse, and feeds it straw.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Franklin, why don’t we just come out and say it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Say what, Eleanor?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: They're here with their hand out. The room is still.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I mean, please -- what century is this? (to everyone in the stables) ) Why do we care what a ‘king’ or ‘queen’ thinks about us? Daisy has watched closely; still patting the horse.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Hick says I should get a month of columns out of this weekend. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (without looking up) ) Eleanor...

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Hick says this King hates his brother. There’s a column there. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELEANOR (cont'd) One of those medieval rivalries -- who wears the crown? I tell you, they're living in the middle ages!

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: His brother’s met with Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: There’s a column there too. And this is the family we’re having to our home for the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Eleanor, you don’t even live here.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I am staying the night. I told your mother I would do that. Daisy is petting a horse and listening. She chimes in:

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I thought the brother gave up being king so he could marry the woman he loved. Franklin looks up to take a peek at this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Daisy, have you ever met a man who would do that? Franklin goes back to his work.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR CONT'D
dialogues.text: (continues, to Missy) Hick says she thinks the brother might be positioning himself to be the savior of the monarchy, once England has been defeated and the fascists have taken over.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: He’s young, Eleanor This gets the women’s attention. (as he works) So is she. They’re both young. The horse Daisy is petting whinnies; Missy turns to Daisy and puts her finger to her mouth. Daisy then does the sam the horse.  36. FRANKLIN CONT’D (looks up) Now let's give them a break. Can we?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (‘innocently’) Are you saying that to me? Daisy and Missy closely watch this husband and wife excha

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I'm saying it to all of us. INT. LIMOUSINE. DAY. Elizabeth is looking at her arm.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: How’s the sunburn?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I don’t have sunburn.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: It was terribly hot. And there wasn’t any shade.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I am not sunburned.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (to Cameron) Why doesn’t she have any ointment?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I don’t need any ointment. Cameron turns around from the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Should we talk through the itinerary, sir?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You're not going to get ill?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Leaning backwards like that, in the car.  37.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Bertie gets ill when he looks back in a moving car.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I haven't for a long time--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That's because you're now always in the backseat. Still I make sure he keeps looking forward. I taught him to do that.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I f-feel fine.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Because you're looking forward.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Perhaps we should stop and meet some people. Wouldn't that be a good idea?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: (confused) But... We've just left... We're almost there. I don't think there are any more towns until... He looks to the driver who shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: It's just a country road now.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Still...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: He wants a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (looks at his watch) We don’t want to be e-e-e-arly.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No. No we don’t. Oh God no.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: And I'd like to meet some Americans.  38. EXT. ROADSIDE. DAY. The entourage of limousines and police cars have pulled o The roadside is deserted. There is a stone wall and a fie behind that. The King and Queen are out of the car. He sm looks around. Others mill around not knowing what to do. A farmer on a tractor drives by harvesting wheat. The Kin smiles and waves. The farmer stares at him and drives pas The Queen looks out at the empty field and the tractor.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (about the Farmer) Doesn't he want to meet you?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: He's busy. The King smokes. Queen watches him.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (quietly, under her breath) I know how important this is. You're not going to let the side down. Don’t worry. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That is what I’ve been telling myself too. Bertie turns to Cameron.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: You started to say about the weekend's itinerary.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: (takes out his notebook) You will be staying in the Roosevelt house. Adjoining rooms. In fact, it is the President's mother's house, and she will officially be your hostess. A car goes by. Bertie waves.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Where is the President's house?  39.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: This is where he lives. When he's not in Washington.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: With his m-m-mother? He doesn't have a house?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: He has a room.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: And his wife?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: She lives in another house. Hers.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: And he doesn't--?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Which she shares with other -- women. Who make furniture.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I'm sorry? Bertie has finished his cigarette, he lights another one.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Furniture. They make it. Build it. They're couples. They're the sort who like each other.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: And the President's wife lives with them?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Yes. The farmer on the tractor drives by again, a little close this time. Bertie smiles and waves. The farmer just stare at him and drives past, plowing.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Where is this furniture factory-house?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: About a mile away from the mother's house.  40.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I see. I think it was a good thing we changed our minds and did not bring Lilibet with us, Bertie. It does not sound like the type of weekend where you bring the children. Four or five curious cows, in the field across the road, to the fence and watch. Bertie watches them and smiles an then waves.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (to Elizabeth) Cows. We have cows.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: The Ambassador's wife, after having visited Hyde Park...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Why do they call it that?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Hyde Park? That’s in London. It's confusing to me.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I don't know. Our Ambassador's wife wrote - and I think you need to hear this. She wrote after staying a night with the Roosevelts in their home (he reads) "It is a dismal house, extremely badly run, and most uncomfortable." Bertie watches the farmer on the tractor drive by one mor time, unsmiling. The cows stare and moo at him. EXT. GATE-HOUSE. DAY. The King and Queen's motorcade turns into the drive on th Roosevelt home. EXT. DRIVE. DAY. The motorcade drives down the tree-lined drive.  41.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: Half of his cabinet had been against the visit. The country, they said, was in no position to take sides in another European War. EXT. FRONT OF HOUSE. DAY. The motorcade approaches the house. Franklin is on the fr steps, sitting in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: So Franklin invited them here to the country, where, out of the spotlight, we could all relax and just be ourselves. EXT. FRONT OF HOUSE. DAY. The cars stop and the King and Queen are helped out of th and walk up the steps and greet the smiling President, th Mother, Eleanor, and others who are around him. EXT. FRONT OF HOUSE / INT. HALLWAY. DAY. The King and Queen are shown into the house. All go in ex for Franklin. As soon as the King and Queen are in, Qualt lifts up Franklin and quickly carries him in his arms aro side of the house. EXT. FRONT OF HOUSE. DAY. DAISY is at distance watching.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: Looking back, I now see how important this day was, to them, to us, to the world. And of course -- as it turned out, to me. EXT. FRONT OF HOUSE / INT. HALLWAY. DAY. King and Queen are looking around, obviously commenting o nice the house is, although we hear none of this. They no through the side window, Franklin being carried by. They pretend to ignore it.  42. EXT. SIDE OF HOUSE. DAY. Franklin is carried through a back door into the living r INT. HALLWAY / LIVING ROOM. DAY. In the hallway, the Royals are waiting.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Oh, what lovely ships. A shelf of model ships in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: My son built them when he was a boy.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: How very clever. (to Bertie) Wasn't that clever?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: T-t-terribly clever. As Eleanor points out some stuff birds:

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: He also did the birds... as a boy. They all try and look ‘interested’ at the birds.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Until the taxidermy smells made him ill. He’ll tell you about it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I shall look forward to that. The door to the living room opens and they are shown in t an already seated and smiling Franklin. INT. ELIZABETH’S BEDROOM. DAY. A Bedroom done in chintz where Eleanor is showing Elizabe where she will be staying. Awkward pause. Their hollow footsteps on the hard wood floor.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Charming.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Hopefully not too small.  43. Elizabeth just 'smiles.' She goes to the window and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Look at that view. You must tell me about everything. Eleanor follows her to the window. They both look out at field.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (pointing) That's -- the field.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (nodding) We have fields just like that.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (pointing) Those hills -- lead down to the river. The awkwardness has gotten painful. They have nothing to to each other.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: So that's where they go. A creak of the floor makes Eleanor turn around. Daisy is the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Daisy? What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You're just standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I came to see if I could be any... They just look at her. Daisy turns to Eleanor expecting a introduction, but Eleanor just looks at her, so Daisy ver self-consciously tries a curtsey which she doesn’t quite off and then she hurries out of the room. Eleanor turns back to Elizabeth who is looking over the b now.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I call you -- Elizabeth?  Elizabeth is stunned, but tries not to show it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No. No. (then) So these are the beds -- you mentioned.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Yes. Those are them.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: How clever of these women to decide to be carpenters. INT. UPSTAIRS LANDING. DAY.
Daisy clearly is the only person not busy, with nothing t Qualters and Cameron, carrying his briefcase, are heading stairs toward her. As they meet:

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: What are you doing skulking around up here?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (smiling) You know me, I'm always skulking. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: Mr. Cameron’s with the embassy -- this is Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: (as he shakes her hand) How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Showing the gentleman his room?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Daisy--? (to Qualters) ) I don't recall a 'Daisy' on tonight's dinner list.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: Oh Daisy's not a guest. She's--. What are you, Daisy?  45.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I'm part of the furniture. The men laugh at the joke, and continue down the hall; sh smiles and starts down the hallway as Mother comes out of King’s bedroom; Daisy steps out of her way.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Is there anything I can help with, Mrs Roosevelt?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (holding her chest) Oh, Daisy. You startled me. She hurries along. Daisy, with nothing to do, slowly walk down the hall. INT. STUDY. DAY. Daisy knocks on a door, doesn't wait for a 'come in' and the door to Franklin's study. Franklin is at his desk, a tray in front of him, which he is carefully arranging. Daisy closes the door -- she is obviously very comfortabl coming in and out of Franklin's study.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Is my wife behaving herself?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Has my mother calmed down?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: She’s fine!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: It’s like a madhouse.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. All quiet on the upstairs front. She throws herself into a big soft chair and puts her fee up. She is very relaxed here. She watches him as he begin mix and then shake the drinks.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: He's definitely younger than I'd imagined. For a King, you know....  46.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Is he...

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: And they both seem nervous. That surprised me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (shaking the drinks) Without some help from us, Daisy -- there soon might not be an England -- to be King of. So I'd be nervous too. She watches him shake the cocktails.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: So many of our countrymen seem to dislike England now. But who better than two such fine young people to maybe change all that. Anyway, that’s why they’re here. Thinking about this, he shakes a little too long. He now notices what he has been doing, stops, opens the shaker, the drink spills.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Damn it. Daisy is surprised by this show of temper and nerves. Franklin starts to clean up. Daisy gets up and helps him.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Let me do it. He sits back and lights a cigarette as she cleans up the in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (as she cleans up) They seem very nice people. Franklin smiles and lets her clean up the rest; she is ve near him; as he watches her:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Later tonight, after the dinner and all that is over, what do you say, you and I get out of here? Go someplace quiet. I think I’1l need that.  47.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (as she cleans) Well -- I think I’m free. (smiles) She is very close to him; she looks up, kisses him sweetl the cheek, pats his head gently.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: It’s going to be a big, big success. And she continues to clean up the spill. INT. PINK BEDROOM. DAY. A bedroom done in Pink where Bertie has just opened a sma traveling liquor cabinet and is beginning to make himself drink, though his attention is on a series of pictures on wall. He turns when he hears a creak. It is Elizabeth. Th are both already dressed for the dinner.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Oh -- it's you.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: We share a bath. (She has come through their shared bathroom. )

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: So I was t-t-told.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: So we don't have to go through the...

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Yes. He takes a sip of his drink.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What were you looking at when I came in?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: These prints. (He gets closer to them.) I just told the President's mother how humorous I found them. Elizabeth is looking closely at them.  48.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What are they of--?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: British soldiers. The 1812 War. Cartoons actually. Mocking them. Us. He takes a bigger sip.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: They put you in a room with--?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: The mother tried to apologize. I told her I found them funny. (he finishes his drink) She said she tried to remove them, but her son insisted.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Why would he do that? What was he trying to say?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I don't know. He bends over the cabinet and begins to pour himself anot I don't know. He knows this is important. He knows why we’re here.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: May I have a drink too? She looks at the pictures on the wall, as he pours her a drink. How many have you had?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: The mother just left. He hands her the drink.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Cheers. She apologized for everything. For Eleanor m-m-mostly. And for the hot dogs.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Hot dogs? What are you talking about, Bertie?  49.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: It appears that at the picnic tomorrow-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: There's a picnic tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: In our honour.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You hate picnics.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: At the picnic, the President's wife has organized that hot dogs be served as our main dish. I gather she's even publicized this in the column she writes. They sip their drinks, lost in thought, then:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Are they trying to make fun of us?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I d-d-don't kn-kn-know. What do you think? INT. LIVING ROOM / STUDY. DAY. Light knock on the door, then Qualters peeks his head in.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: His Majesty will be down shortly. Franklin nods and sips his drink. Is that a drinks tray, sir? Franklin doesn't answer. Qualters and Daisy share a look ‘what's going to happen?’ INT. PINK BEDROOM. DAY. The King and Queen, with drinks in their hands. Elizabeth once again staring at the pictures/cartoons on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: These are revolting. They make our seamen look like monkeys. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH (cont'd) I can't believe he thought these would make you laugh, Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I 'laughed'.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: They're trying to make us seem -- common. Your brother would never have stood for this. I'm sorry, but he wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I th-th-think if we j-j-just ignore the-the-these--.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Please, stop stuttering! (Pause. They both sip then) I'm sorry. I'm very sorry. I didn't mean it, Bertie. I think I have a headache. My face feels hot. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: It's the sunburn.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have said.. I didn't mean...

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I am not my brother.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Thank God for that.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: And you are not the D-d-duchess of Windsor. You are better than that. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I just hate to see you...

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: See me...?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Laughed at. She looks back at the pictures, and sips, then:  51. How do you eat a hot dog?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I believe with your hands. INT. LIVING ROOM / STUDY. DAY. Door opens and Maid 1 (Mary) enters with a full tea tray. carries the tray to Franklin's desk -- stops when she see drinks tray already there. She hesitates, then sets her t beside the other.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (smiling) You're not going to tell anyone, are you, Mary?

dialogues.speaker: MAID 1
dialogues.text: Not a soul, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: Mary, we all knew, was Mother's spy. Mother had them too. The Maid goes.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PINK BEDROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Bertie and Elizabeth sitting on his bed, drinking.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: There was in my room -- left there -- I'm sure so I couldn't help but see it -- a copy of that magazine with the article.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Who would have left it?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Maybe a m-m-maid. They look Irish. Except for the one who looks Jewish. We're not home.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I-I'd leave it untouched. Another drink?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Why not? The drinks cabinet is now on the bed with them. make another drink.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: The President seemed...?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: That was a question. I'm asking you.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I can't tell yet. He hands her the drink.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: It was peculiar -- being greeted on the s-s-teps. Then ushered in -- and, di-di-did you see through the window? Did you follow that?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: We were told he could walk with a cane.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: He has two canes.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: They seem to be mostly for show. INT. LIVING ROOM. DAY. Now it is MOTHER coming through the living room, 52. He starts to and she opens the door to Franklin’s study without even knocking.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: Mother, who had a sixth sense for sniffing out alcohol, was on the warpath. Mother’s father had been a nasty drunk.  53.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDY. DAY
dialogues.text: MOTHER enters and Daisy suddenly stands up. Franklin just ‘smiles’. Mother is looking at the drinks tray.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Is he coming down?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: What is that doing in here? She goes and picks up the drinks tray -- glasses rattle.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Leave it, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I thought we agreed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: That's not true.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I'm not going to let the King and Queen of England see us--

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (shouts ) Dammit, I said -- leave it!! Daisy, close the door. Daisy turns to close the door as Eleanor hurries in:

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What's happening? Why are you shouting?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Close the door, Daisy!

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Should I stay?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Just close it. Daisy closes the door and stays.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: He's brought out the drinks tray, Eleanor.  54.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Franklin, you promised.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: As I said to Mother, that's not true.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Maybe after dinner!!

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Don’t shout, Mother. We have guests. INT. LIVING ROOM. DAY. Servants listening the hallway to the argument in the Stu

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I know we have guests! And I know who they are! And my son is not going to serve them cocktails!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: They’re my guests!! INT. STUDY. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: It’s my house!!

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You’re the one who wants us to live here.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Eleanor, don’t--.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Give me the tray.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (to Franklin) Isn’t it true?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: No. Yes. (then) I’m the President!!

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Stop this. Please stop this!!  55. INT. PINK BEDROOM. DAY. Bertie and Elizabeth are still drinking on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I have the programme for tomorrow's ‘event.' He searches in his jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: It’s been printed. Here. He tries to show her, she doesn't take it. She sips.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: This is for the hot dog picnic?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: There will be entertainment as well.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Perhaps I should be surprised.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (looking at the program) Indians.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Indians. (reads ) "Ish-Ti-Opi."

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What???

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: He's called here "The Indian Baritone." So he's going to sing. There's "Princess Te Ata." She is going to show us "The Indian Corn Ceremony."

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Oh god.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: "Accompanied by Kurkus Pahitu on the tom-tom."  56.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: There's our incentive not to be hung- over. Perhaps our only incentive. The ‘tom-tom.' 'Hot dogs.' ‘Cartoons of British naval officers as monkeys.' Knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Come in. Cameron is at the door.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: The President is waiting for you in his study, your Majesty. He said it was time for -- ‘children’s hour.’ Bertie is confused.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: (explains) Drinks. Bertie nods, finishes his drink and stands.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: And the Queen?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: She's been allowed more time to relax. Elizabeth smiles at Bertie and sips her drink.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (leans over and kisses her on the cheek, then sighs) Here we go... He gets up. INT. STUDY. DAY. The room is icy. Franklin sits behind his desk. Daisy sta a corner. Mother sits, a frozen expression on her face. Eleanor sits to one side, obviously unhappy. A knock on the door. The door opens. Qualters announces:

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: His Majesty.  57. Bertie comes into the room. Mother immediately stands and curtsies. Daisy copies her. She looks to Eleanor who just ‘politely nods' to Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (a big smile) Come in. Come in, my friend. Forgive me for not getting up. Franklin holds out his hand. Bertie goes to the desk and shakes hands. On the desk now are the drinks tray and a tray for tea. Bertie looks at the competing trays.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Sir, my Mother does not approve of cocktails. Mother's face is very stern. And thinks you might rather have a cup of tea. Bertie looks around the room, then at the competing trays

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: M-m-my m-m-mother would have said the s-s-s-same thing. Actually I-I-I-I-I prefer a-a-a-a... The suspense builds. Daisy holds her breath. The others l at each other, then finally ++. cocktail. Franklin laughs, the others follow and then Bertie laughs pleased with his joke. As we watch Daisy who exhales, relieved that the King finally got it out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN VOICE
dialogues.text: (as he begins to pour) A man after my own heart... Daisy starts to sip her drink, then stops, when she sees Mother watching. INT. KITCHEN. EVENING. The kitchen crowded with servants, cooks, getting the din ready.  58. INT. LIVING ROOM. EVENING. The guests for dinner having cocktails. Bertie and the President are together - others listening intently as Fra tells a joke:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: So she said: ‘I’m so pleased to meet you, Mr. President, I’ve only met three Americans. Joe Kennedy, J.P. Morgan, and Fred Astaire.’ He pauses for the punch line:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (continues) ‘Thank God,’ I said, ‘you met Mr. Astaire, or what would you think of the rest of us?’ The guests laugh. INT. HALLWAY/LIVING ROOM. EVENING. Elizabeth comes down the hallway; just before she enters living room, she takes a deep breath, puts on her public and as she walks in there is a 'buzz.' She and Bertie sha look, she is nervous but acting confident. Guests curtsey shakes their hands. Mother introduces her. Eleanor greets Queen, and is obliged to curtsey, which she does as perfunctorily as she can. Bertie watches his wife; Frankl his attention back. INT. STUDY. EVENING. In the study doorway, peeking into the living room are a Maids -- and Daisy. The Butler comes up behind them and is telling them they shouldn't be there. The Maids hurry off to work; Daisy is suddenly alone. INT. LIVING ROOM / HALLWAY / DINING ROOM. EVENING. Mother stands ringing a little bell -- for dinner. The guests start to pair off. All watch as the King goes righ up to Mother, with his arm out:

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Mrs. R-r-r-r-r-ro-ro...  59.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (taking his arm) I'd love to, your majesty. And they lead the procession into the dining room where t table is beautifully set for approximately twenty. Servan stand, Mother is beaming. Right behind is Franklin who mo painfully on his braces and sticks. Elizabeth is 'pretend to hold onto his arm. On his other arm is Qualters, unobtrusively, letting Franklin hold on.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (to Elizabeth, a joke) We could have sold tickets to this dinner, and made ourselves a pile of money. She doesn’t know what to make of this; he winks at her, a they continue toward the dining room. EXT. FRONT OF HOUSE. EVENING. Up in the sky is a gorgeous full moon. Even the chauffeurs outside are divided by class tonight; one group, the permanent employees of the wealthy, and in another, five or six drivers hired for this night. These drivers talk and smoke among themselves under a tree by t driveway. The cars are parked along the drive. One of them notices the moon, and taps another on the shoulder. The conversation stops as they look at the moon

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRIVER
dialogues.text: (he’s Irish-American) You think it’s full?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND DRIVER
dialogues.text: I think it’s got another day.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRIVER
dialogues.text: I think it’s full. Let’s see what Daisy thinks. For the first time we see Daisy sitting on the front step the house. . Behind her the house is lit up. From the ope porch, a small military band is heard playing "You For Me She too is looking up at the moon. The FIRST DRIVER leaves the group and goes up to her.  60.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRIVER
dialogues.text: Daisy? She is startled, having been lost in her thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Oh hello, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRIVER
dialogues.text: You think it’s full tonight?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: What? Oh -- yes. That moon certainly is full.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRIVER
dialogues.text: (shouts back) She says I’m right!

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (suddenly worried) Oh, I didn’t know you--. I could be wrong. I don’t know for--.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRIVER
dialogues.text: Do you need a ride home?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Me? No. No thank you. I have my car. I just.... Such an important night. She stands up, notices the other drivers from this group looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRIVER
dialogues.text: Is it? I don’t know. What’s one king more or less? He still has to put his pants on one leg at a time.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND DRIVER
dialogues.text: (calls) Did you curtsey for the Queen, Daisy?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (calls back) I certainly did, Tommy! And I think I did it right. (smiles) I didn’t fall down!  61. They laugh. The other group of official Chauffeurs ignore them.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD DRIVER
dialogues.text: How come you’re not inside there, Daisy?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Me? Oh I don’t belong in there. I’m glad to see you working, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD DRIVER
dialogues.text: It’s just for the one night...

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Well it’s something... A MAID comes from around the house with food for the driv The official chauffeurs ignore this. The others line up to eat. Daisy watches this from a distance:

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRIVER
dialogues.text: (to Maid, joking) Can I take some home for my dog?

dialogues.speaker: FOURTH DRIVER
dialogues.text: He doesn’t have a dog. Laughter at their situation. As Daisy wanders off into th dark:

dialogues.speaker: MAID 2
dialogues.text: (to one of the younger chauffeurs) Touch me there again, you'll be wearing it and not eating it... Laughter. EXT. FRONT/SIDE OF HOUSE. EVENING. We follow Daisy as she turns the corner of the house to t porch where the military band is finishing playing a song under strings of festive lights. A Maid with a tray of snacks has come out and waits.

dialogues.speaker: BAND LEADER
dialogues.text: Fifteen minutes, gentlemen.  62. And the band members stand, and circle the Maid with the of food.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM. EVENING
dialogues.text: Franklin sits next to the Queen; he taps a spoon against glass to get the table’s attention.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
