dialogues.text: (whispers to the Queen) You'll forgive me for not getting up. (raises his glass, to the Table) To His Majesty, the King. Suddenly all the guests stand -- chairs pushed back. Only Franklin and the Royals remain seated. The Guests all rai glasses and repeat:

dialogues.speaker: GUESTS
dialogues.text: To His Majesty, the King. Everyone drinks. As the guests begin to sit, Franklin has an afterthought:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (toasts) And to Her Majesty, the Queen! The guests hesitate, some stand again immediately, some hesitate, and look among themselves -- what to do; they a finally stand.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: (to Eleanor, next to him, as he stands) Actually, normally, we wouldn't toast the Queen. And they drink. Some repeating “To Her Majesty, the Queen Some just saying to “The Queen.” Some saying nothing or j ‘Welcome.” During this confusion, the Queen, taken aback by this afterthought, and what actually is being toasted, drinks well. Her drinking to her own toast gets the attention of Mrs Astor, one of the guests. She turns to her neighbor.  63.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. ASTOR
dialogues.text: (under her breath) She drank to herself. EXT. LAWN. EVENING. Daisy still stands at a short distance from the house, looking back. The house is lit up and looking magnificent romantic, festive. The band again is playing on the porch She stands lost in her thoughts. She smokes a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Shoot! Daisy turns, there is Missy leaning over looking at her shoes; she has stepped in something.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (wiping her shoes) Those damn horses. And these are my best shoes. Daisy approaches her, looks down at her black and white shoes.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: It’s not the horses’ fault--.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (trying to clean her shoe) I know. I know. You like them. I’ve been looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Do you need a handkerchief?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Come here. Daisy comes to Missy who puts her hand on Daisy’s shoulde keep her balance as she cleans the horse shit off her sho The band music continues from the porch.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: We saw you out here--.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: We??

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Franklin’s asked me to tell you that you could go home. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISSY (cont'd) He thinks he’s going to be occupied with the King all evening now. Daisy turns back toward the house, try to hide her disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Of course he is... INT. HALLWAY / DINING ROOM. EVENING. The soup course is about to be served. A waiter holds a stopwatch at his side. A Maid whispers:

dialogues.speaker: MAID 2
dialogues.text: What are you doing with that?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: (under his breath) We've been told the Queen is served exactly 30 seconds after the King. The King is served his soup, and the Waiter starts the stopwatch ticking. Suddenly we hear an enormous crash. A serving tray with a pile of plates has collapsed, start everyone.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MAID 1
dialogues.text: (holding the King’s soup) I don't know. No one touched it.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I su-su-suppose an angel just passed - a ve-ve-ry clumsy one. He smiles at his joke. Franklin leads the laughter, and g Bertie a big nodding smile. The King is very pleased with himself. Mother is embarrassed but trying not to show it. Franklin looks to Eleanor who smiles, and then nods her h she has appreciated the King’s sense of humor and grace.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (to Cameron, about the King’s joke) ) That was very good...  65. Maids 1 & 2 have quickly started to clean up.

dialogues.speaker: MAID 2
dialogues.text: (to the other, explaining the crash) It’s the full moon. The Maid 1 nods.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. ASTOR
dialogues.text: (to a neighbor) I hope those weren't mine. (to Cameron, another neighbor, explaining) She didn't have enough plates. EXT. LAWN. EVENING. Missy and Daisy sit on a bench, under a tree; the house a front of them, and the music. Both look at the moon. Both

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: She doesn’t leave him alone. She doesn’t let him relax.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Is that what he tells you?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Does he talk about her with you, Daisy?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: With me? Why would he talk about his wife with me?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: I don’t know how he stands it. Missy has finished her cigarette and tosses it on the gro and stands.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Stands what?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Eleanor's always off to places. Meetings. How he must miss it. Daisy tosses her cigarette down and stands.  66.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Miss what? Missy starts to head back to the house, Daisy right behin her.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Having a happy married life together.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I don’t think that is the President’s fault --.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: I wasn’t saying--. I think it pains him more than we can know -- not having a wife to care for him. As they head toward the brightly lit house, we hear only their voices:

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VOICE
dialogues.text: This morning she didn’t even know about his sinuses.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY VOICE
dialogues.text: Didn’t she?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VOICE
dialogues.text: She said she didn’t. It’s sort of like they’ve become just -- friends. Just good friends.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY VOICE
dialogues.text: She is a_ busy woman.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VOICE
dialogues.text: She's his wife... INT. DINING ROOM. EVENING. Franklin is telling the table the story of Bertie being g the choice of tea or a highball.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: “My mother treats me in the exactly same way, Mr. President... But I too prefer a cocktail. Who wouldn't?” Great laughter; Bertie enjoys the attention and is smilin soaking it in.  67. Mother is not too keen about telling this story; and Elizabeth is a bit surprised. But the table finds it very funny. Eleanor especially is now laughing. Maid 1 is whispering in Mother's ear. INT. KITCHEN. EVENING. In the kitchen, Mr Johnson, Mother's English butler, stan his coat, holding his hat. An Aide is with him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I apologize, Madam. For the timing.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE 3
dialogues.text: I've tried to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (very stiff, very proper, very English) Madam, I simply cannot stand by and watch the King of my country being served by....Negroes. For the first time we see the problem -- the two Negro waiters, Nelson and Thomas, stand in the corner listening this.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnson, you are the best butler we have. I understand the situation. (to Aide) Isn't there something we can do?

dialogues.speaker: AIDE 3
dialogues.text: They came with--.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Me. Eleanor, sensing the problem, has followed them into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Mr Thomas and Mr. Nelson are part of the White House staff.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I realize that, Eleanor. What if we kept them in the kitchen?  68.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Mother, we’re not going to hide them in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Eleanor, why are you even involved in this?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You knew we were bringing help. You agreed.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I didn’t know they were -- them.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Either they go, or I go, Ma‘’am. Mother turns to Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: They are not going anywhere. As long as I am here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy and Missy now at the window to the dining room, pee in. Through the window -- The Negro servants enter, Mother an Eleanor behind them; Eleanor smiling to herself, triumphantly. We look around the table, Franklin laughing Bertie listening to someone on his right, etc. Missy touches Daisy's shoulder to move her along:

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Do you need a ride home--?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (still staring into the window) No. Along the house, the English Butler, Johnson, bag in hand walking toward the front of the house and the road. Daisy stares into the window.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Look at him.  69. We see what she is looking at: Franklin is now leaning ov the table telling a story -- everyone is enthralled, then burst into laughter, including Eleanor. He is obviously i his element. DAISY’S VOICE They love him. MISSY’S VOICE Who doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I suppose I better go.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: I’1l walk you to your car. The two women head around the house. DAISY’S VOICE I can’t help but keep thinking about the King’s brother giving up his crown. For love. A real life Romeo and Juliet. Franklin and I talked about it. MISSY’S VOICE Did you? And what did he say, Daisy? DAISY’S VOICE He said that sort of thing was very English. MISSY’S VOICE Where’s your car?

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM. EVENING
dialogues.text: A maid carries in a tray of food, as she approaches the K she trips and the plates are flung right past the King. Mother immediately looks at one of the Negro waiters, Tho who gestures that he didn’t do anything. The Maid is horrified. Silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Nu-nu-number 2! Laughter Eleanor enjoying this, as Maids go to clean up t mess. 2nd Maid whispers to the lst, as if explaining it a  70.

dialogues.speaker: MAID 2
dialogues.text: I told you -- it’s the moon.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FRONT OF HOUSE. EVENING
dialogues.text: The full moon. The guests are all leaving, coming out of house, saying their good-byes to Mother. Chauffeurs and d are lined up with their cars. One by one their owners get and are driven off down the tree-lined lane. EXT. LAWN. EVENING. The military band are packing up their things. INT. HALLWAY/ LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. Franklin starts to wheel his chair from the hallway into living room. In the background, the final guests are leav

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Let's go to my study. We'll be left alone in there. Unless you need to--.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: No. No. Franklin stops.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Would you mind pushing? Bertie gets behind Franklin and pushes him into the livin room. Her Majesty has gone to bed?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: She has. And -- your wife?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Who knows? (he laughs) I'm sure. INT. STUDY. NIGHT. Bertie pushes Franklin in, Franklin gestures that he shou close the door.  71.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Night cap? Mother's gone to bed. Still sitting in his wheelchair, he begins to make them drinks. I was worried for her....if one more thing went wrong... Smiles, hands Bertie a drink. (about the drink) ) They worry about me. My Mother and Eleanor. Both their fathers were nasty drunks. Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Cheers. They drink, Bertie is looking around the room.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Do you collect stamps?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I did. I have. I understand you are a serious stamp collector. Perhaps, you would show me some of your stamps.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: You can’t be interested.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: But I am --.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Don’t -- protest. Thank you for the thought, though. Toasts him. When I was a young man -- before my marriage of course -- I found that showing one’s stamps was a very helpful way to get a young woman’s attention.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Was it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: They have to sit close to you. Share the magnifying glass.  72. He ‘winks’ at Bertie. And smiles. But I suppose if your father’s the king... Who needs stamps? Bertie sips his drink. The Queen is certainly a lovely woman. Bertie looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: As is the first lady.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: She’s a -- (choosing his words carefully) strong -- person (smiles) Some days you feel like you don’t even want to get out of bed -- but then these women, they won’t let you do that, will they? He looks at Bertie, who sips his drink and says:

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: What do you do -- to be alone? Bertie looks confused. (explaining) I have my stamps... You need to give them (gestures to those outside -- wherever) a reason not to bother you. You can figure things out in the quiet of your own head. I open up my stamp books and that tells everyone not to bother me. Bertie nods. You were wonderful tonight, young man. Bertie is taken aback by this.  73.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Just what I said. You were graceful. You were confident. You're going to be a very fine king. I'm sure of it.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I don't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Your father would be very proud.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (‘smiling’) I’m not so certain about that. Franklin sips his drink, looking right into Bertie’s eyes

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: If I were your father, I’d be proud. They sip their drinks, Bertie looks around, thinking abou what to say. He smiles; FRANKLIN CONT’D I know -- some men have an entire home as their castle, I only get a study. (then) But then you must have many many castles. Bertie looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: The Queen -- she’s... She worries so much. It’s been hard for her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (a fact) Women worry.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I just stop listening to her sometimes. Forget I said that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Forgotten.  74. Bertie takes a folded up piece of paper out of his inside jacket pocket, and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (explaining) I’ve been asked to say things... He looks up and begins:

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Such a war as we now co-co- contemplate --. The carnage, look at S-S-S-Spain. Ch-children -- b-b- bombed. Tha-tha-that’s what we can expect. It will b-b-be horrific. Beyond anything m-m-man has seen. Bertie takes a sip, then looks up at Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (he tries again) And yet we know some of your countrymen wi-wi-wi-sh my country i- i-i-i-ill... And w-w-want us to fail. And want me to fail wi-th-th- th you... (he looks away) This god damn st-st-stutter... He looks back into his drink.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: What stutter? Bertie is surprised by this, looks closely at Franklin, t

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This god damn polio. They look closely at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think -- they des- deserve better than me. My -- ‘subjects.’ I’m sorry. I don’t know why-why I’m saying this to you. I’m s-s-supposed to be trying to convince you to help us.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Let me confess something now to you. Bertie looks at him.  75.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As you have been so -- honest with me. No one -- ever mentions to me that I can’t move my legs. It’s never referred to. Bertie is very intrigued by this.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not by anyone. I used to think it was because they were embarrassed about it. Franklin starts to stand up out of his wheelchair; Bertie stands to help, Franklin waves him off. As he heads to hi desk, moving slowly on his braces, holding on to the back chairs. FRANKLIN (CONT’D) But now I think it’s because that’s not what they want to see. He sits at his desk, takes a cigarette (his reason for co to the desk), offers one to Bertie as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course we (gestures he and Bertie) think they (gestures everyone out there) see everything that we are. All our flaws. Or transgressions. Or failures. But that is not what they're looking to find when they look to us. And God help us if that ever changes. They look at each other. Think of the disappointment... when they find out what we really are. (smiles) Sometimes it might make one feel an imposter... He is lighting Bertie’s cigarette now so their faces are close. This last comment strikes home for Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (unable to look up as he speaks) They didn’t want me as their King.  76.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I didn’t know they voted for that in England. Bertie smiles. Franklin relaxes behind his desk. FRANKLIN (CONT’D) Pretending at times to be someone we know we aren’t. Young man, that’s what I’ve learned it takes to be a President. And I’m going to hazard a guess that it takes the same damn thing to be a king. He smiles that big smile, smoking his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I’m thinking -- another drink? INT. LIVING ROOM / HALLWAY. NIGHT. The living room is empty; laughter is heard coming from t Study. Missy enters from the hallway, on her way to the study, having obviously been called. She stops when she sees Bertie, come out of the study, smiling to himself. He quietly closes the door behind him; he appears to be a somewhat changed man, at least for the moment -- a new sp in his step; a satisfied smile. At first he doesn’t notice Missy.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (after nearly bumping into her) Pardon me...

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Sir. (corrects herself) I mean, Your Highness. (corrects herself again) Your Majesty... She curtseys. He smiles at her and she watches him head u the steps, two at a time.  77. INT. ELIZABETH’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. Bertie goes through the bathroom, and gently pushes the d open to Elizabeth's bedroom. Elizabeth asleep in bed. Bertie stands for a moment, then ‘coughs.’

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: You're still awake?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Mmmmmmm .

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I think I'll go to sleep. It's late.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Why are you smiling? Are you drunk?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: No. He's a very funny man. Has some wonderful jokes.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Like what? She sits up in bed.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (hesitates, then) I couldn't tell them to you. They're not meant for women.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: They sound very 'funny.'

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: He liked my stories too. Concerned, she turns on bedside lamp.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What stories?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I-I-I told him about the coronation. About how they p-p-put the crown wrong way around. He laughs, she doesn't. And the stepping on my robe so I couldn't move.  78.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have told him that.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Why? He laughed.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: We don't make fun of ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: That's not true.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Not here. Of course he liked those stories, they make us look like fools.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: They make us look like people!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Don't be naive, Bertie. Bertie goes and looks out the window and again there is t full moon.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: He made fun of himself too. He said at the picnic tomorrow--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Oh god that picnic.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (sitting on the bed, smiling) He said that the Indians -- they were Eleanor's ideas. "One of my-my-my wife's crazy ideas." His Mother is furious about it. Franklin's just trying to keep it short.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: He talks about his wife like that to you? I hope you didn't talk about me to him.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I didn't. I wouldn't do that. We didn't talk about you. (then) I asked him -- without mentioning you -- about these hot dogs? What's that about? You want to know what he said? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERTIE (cont'd) (she stares at him) He said he doesn't get the fuss. They're just a good thing to eat ata picnic. There's no 'meaning.' Nothing more.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You didn't say I was concerned?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I believe you--.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: That's not fair.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Three different women tonight asked me if I thought there could ever be an American queen. If we'd ever ‘allow' that.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: That was rude.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Do you have a cigarette? I have smoked all of mine.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: That won't help you sleep.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I know. He gives her a cigarette. Thank you. A light? He lights her cigarette. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I never wanted this life.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It’s hard.  80. Go to bed. I'll be fine. She smokes.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: If there's a war -- and we know there will be -- he believes America could be persuaded to help.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Did you see some of the people here tonight? Hear their names? They're from Germany. Italy.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Their ancestors--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: They're Irish. They're Jews. They hate us, Bertie!! They want to see us fall on our face!! They want to laugh at us!! She starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I think you're wrong. I th-th- think we just need to be a little more confident. He gets up off the bed and heads back to his bedroom. Elizabeth is amazed, stunned by this new attitude; she ha never heard him talk like this before.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Goodnight. I'm not sure I can even sleep. (turns back to her) Finally, he patted me on the knee and said, ‘young ma-ma-man, it's time for you to go to bed." Like a father, I suppose. He's very happy that I am king. (Then one more thing) When he retires, he's going to write detective stories. I told him I love detective stories. She just looked at him. He’s built a cottage. He told me I could come and stay anytime. I love detective stories.  81. He closes the bathroom door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PINK BEDROOM. / EXT. FRONT OF HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bertie, in his pajamas now, sits in a chair in the corner smokes in the dark. He gets up and goes to look at the Wa 1812, anti-British prints on the wall, which are lit only the moonlight, one more time. He strikes a match to take closer look. When noises outside distract him and he shakes out the ma He goes to the window, pulls back the curtain and looks d below. From his perspective, we see an idling car -- having just been brought from the garage. A uniformed officer waits. Qualters and then Missy come out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: (to Missy) Do you want to drive? Without answering she goes around to the driver's seat; Qualters is telling the officer something. Bertie watches this officer then hurry off. Qualters gets in and drives Missy off. Bertie watches the car go down the long drive; he looks u the moon. He is about to leave the window when a second c is driven up by the Officer, this car is Franklin's. Suddenly the light in the room is turned on, startling Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I thought you were asleep.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (whispering) Then why did you turn the light on? Outside a car is driving off. Bertie looks out the window

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Who’s that?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: It’s Franklin. Bertie goes to the wall switch and turns the light off.  82.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Can we call home? I want to speak with Lilibet.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: What?? It's--. Looks at the clock.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It's morning there. She's up. We know she's up. They hear another car pull up outside. They look at each other, then both go to the window, pull back the curtains and peek out: THREE WOMEN sit in an idling covertible, as Eleanor hurri from the house and gets into the back seat; there is muff laughter/giggling from the women. The King and Queen watc they drive off:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Who are they? With Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I’m just guessing now -- but: the ones who made your bed?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (totally confused) Maids?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: The furniture makers.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Oh. Where do you think they’re going, Bertie?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Back to the furniture factory where they all live? I’m just guessing. Then:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I want to call home.  83. INT. DAISY’S BEDROOM. NIGHT Daisy, in a white nightgown, lies in her bed, her bedshee twisted, unable to sleep, staring off toward the window a the full moon. She is restless, tries to lie on a differe side, then reaches and turns on a little bedside lamp, an picks up a book to read.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: No one could sleep that night. She impetuously jumps out of bed, grabs a sweater from a on the back of her bedroom door, and goes out, quietly closing the door behind her. We see for the first time, on the back of the door, visib only when closed is a framed official portrait of Preside Roosevelt -- the kind they hang in post offices. EXT. DAISY’S HOUSE PORCH. NIGHT. Daisy swings gently in the porch swing, pushing with her feet; smoking, staring out into the night. The full moon looking down upon her. Suddenly she gets up, quickly stubbing out her cigarette the ashtray. She rushes inside, then quickly stops and gr the screen door to keep it from slamming shut and making noise. EXT. DAISY’S HOUSE / INT. DAISY’S CAR. NIGHT. IN HER CAR, dressed now, she sits in the dark; only the reflection of the moon on the hood of the car; she sighs big sigh and releases the brake and the car rolls a littl Only when it has rolled a comfortable distance from the h does she turn on the engine and then the headlights. And heads off, the moon in front of her, it’s as if she is be pulled by the moon. EXT. PINK BEDROOM. NIGHT. Elizabeth sits on the bed waiting. Bertie comes in from t hallway in his robe.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: They're putting us through. Phone in the room rings. Elizabeth answers it.  84.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yes. Yes, put her on. (short pause, then) Darling! It's Mummy! How are you? I'm sure it is. Is Margaret with you? Tell her -- it's still night here. She smiles at Bertie -- Margaret will get a kick out of hearing that, she thinks. But Margaret clearly doesn't understand this concept of t differences. Tell her -- it's night. It's dark. The sun isn't.... What is she saying? Yes I know, it's morning there. But it's... I'm not trying to scare her, dear. Why is what I'm saying scary? The sun will come up, tell her that, just not--. Holding her hand over the phone, to Bertie: She's upset. She's thinks.... I don't know what she thinks. Listens. Now Lilibet’s crying too. He takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello, my Lilibet! Tell your sister it's because the world is round. It goes around the sun so--. It--. (to Elizabeth) They're crying. (what to do? Then into phone) Oh look, the sun has just come out. It was behind a cloud all this time. Tell Margaret that we’re sorry to have confused her. That's right. We're fine. We just wanted to say hello. Lilibet? Lilibet? (to Elizabeth) She's gone. (then) She rung off.  85. INT. DAISY’S CAR / EXT. THE ROAD NEAR TOP COTTAGE. NIGHT. Daisy drives along the main road; she pulls the car onto patch of grass on the side of the road, and cuts the engi She gets out and starts to head into the woods. EXT. WOODS. NIGHT. Daisy climbs, lit only by the moon. She seems to be in no rush to get anywhere -- rather enjoying the night, the magical moonlight, the mystery of the woods, the cries of owls, the barking and howling of distant dogs.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: If ever I missed him, there was a place he’d built for me to come, and be alone, and miss him. EXT. TOP COTTAGE. NIGHT. She reaches the top, her destination -- and there is Top Cottage, dark and bathed by the moon. EXT/INT. TOP COTTAGE. NIGHT. Daisy sits on the porch where she has sat so often before with Franklin, and where she now sits looking off at the distant hills. She lights a cigarette and baths in the be of the evening. Behind her, the house is dark; lit only, as is everything else, by the moon. Suddenly through the glass door, we see a shadowy naked female figure scurry, then stop, seem to pick up somethin and for a instant we see her lit, then the lighter is clo and all we see is the glow of her cigarette. Daisy stares off, utterly oblivious to all of this. All of a sudden a flashlight shines in Daisy's face, startling her, and making her jump up. MAN’S VOICE What the hell are you doing here? Daisy, trying to calm herself from the shock, shades her and sees:

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Tommy? What the hell are you doing here?  86.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t be up here now.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Why? Why not? Daisy, still covers her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Can you get that out of my face, please? He lowers the flashlight and she sees, lit now by the flashlight, a pair of shoes on the ground -- women’s blac and white shoes -- Missy’s.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: You really shouldn’t be up here, Daisy. Daisy stares at the shoes. Two bare feet appear beside the shoes in the light of the flashlight. It is Missy.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (very friendly) Daisy! How nice to see you up here. ' Daisy looks at Missy, who is finishing a last button; the her bare feet, then at the shoes. A door closes in the house. She turns and looks there, th it all suddenly dawns on her.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Oh my god... Oh my god... She bolts for the woods.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Stop her!

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: (going after Daisy) Daisy, stop! Don’t go in--. EXT. WOODS. NIGHT. Daisy hurries through the forest.  87. Qualters runs after her, and immediately gets caught in t brambles and trips, falls down.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: Fuck. Fuck... Missy follows, still barefoot.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (as she heads into the woods ) Daisy! Ouch. Daisy! EXT. WOODS. NIGHT. Daisy madly fights her way through a brush, then falls an begins sliding, then rolling down a steep hill. EXT. WOODS. NIGHT. Missy fights her way through the underbrush.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (calling) Come on, Daisy! What the hell are you doing? Daisy! EXT. WOODS. NIGHT. Qualters is now sliding down the same hill, holding onto limbs and bushes and he hurries down. EXT. WOODS. NIGHT. Daisy lies on the ground; she hears Missy’s voice. MISSY’S VOICE Daisy! Come on, Daisy! The voice is getting closer. Daisy starts to stand up, wh out of the dark a hand grabs her arm.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS VOICE
dialogues.text: I have her! Daisy suddenly bites the arm, pushes away Qualters and plunges into the dark, only to fall again. Qualters flashlight falls onto the trapped Daisy. Missy charges through the brush and hurries to the voice.  88.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: Get up. Get up, Daisy. You fucking bit me. What is wrong with you? Daisy is crying, very upset, nearly hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: I said get up. He pulls her up, as Missy appears.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (to Daisy) It’s all right. It’s all right. I understand. Just calm down now.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: She fucking bit me.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: You'll live. (to Daisy) Take a deep breath. (to Qualters) Let go of her. Let go... Qualters lets go of Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Now, that’s better isn’t it? Now why are you so upset? Missy tries to touch Daisy’s cheek.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Don’t touch me.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: What do you think happened? Missy is breathing heavily. She looks at Qualters then: (desperate) Do you want to see the President? For the first time Daisy looks at her. He’s just up there. I think he’d very much like to see you. Missy picks some leaves and pine needles out of her hair. Look at you. We don’t want him to see you like this, do we?  89. Daisy stares at her. Tommy, could I have your handkerchief? He gives her his handkerchief. She licks it and begins to clean Daisy’s face. As she cleans, and as Daisy stares at her, no longer crying:

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: This is a very important weekend for everyone. I wouldn’t want any of us to forget that. So we all need to be on our best behavior. Don’t we? Missy continues to fuss, pulling out a leaf from Daisy's tangled hair... Suddenly, Daisy pushes Missy hard; Missy falls, and Daisy bolts again and again charges into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (on the ground) Daisy!! Get a hold of yourself! Stop this! God damn it! Missy looks at Qualters. Winded, she notices her nose is bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: Don’t look at me. I didn’t do anything. He starts to head back toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: Fuck this, I’m going to stay with the President. EXT. WOODS. NIGHT. Daisy is running, desperate, crying; she fights her way through the bushes. She slips and falls, struggles and hurries to get up and throws herself, down the hill. Anyt to get away. She is a mess; twigs, leaves in her hair; she’s cut her l ripped her dress. She runs recklessly down the hill, tripping, grabbing ont branches to steady herself until she pushes herself out o bush and literally falls onto a road.  90. EXT. THE ROAD NEAR TOP COTTAGE. NIGHT. She looks first one way, and then the other down the road and no more than fifty yards away is her car. Just where left it. EXT. THE ROAD NEAR TOP COTTAGE. NIGHT. She reaches her car, opens the door, gets in, and discove her keys are gone. In a panic, she starts to look on the floor, on the seat when:

dialogues.speaker: MISSY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Here. Missy is in the backseat, dried blood on her face from he bloody nose. She shows her the keys.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: No. Get out of here. Missy reaches and touches Daisy's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (shaking her off) Get out of here--

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Daisy. No one says anything for a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: He wants to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY'S
dialogues.text: (shouts ) I don't want to talk to him!! Daisy sits very still.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: You're being ... silly. They both notice lights and the noise of a car engine com down the dirt driveway. Daisy doesn’t know what to do; an Missy doesn’t know what Daisy is going to do. As the headlights get closer, Daisy reaches for the door handle, but Missy grabs her arm and holds her.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: He’s going home. He’s headed home.  gl. Franklin is being driven by Qualters; the car passes righ Daisy's car, inches away. Franklin in shadow and silhouet is in the backseat; he doesn’t look out. Daisy covers her face. As Franklin’s car drives off, Missy lets go of Daisy’s ar

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: You want a cigarette? (no response) I want you to listen to me. And I want you to listen very very carefully. Understand? Look at me. Understand? Daisy looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: What can you say?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Understand?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: I read all your letters, Daisy. And his -- to you. He knows this. Probably wants this... I read the letter where he asks you to live with him. I know you are -- (searches the for the word) intimate. I've known since the day it happened.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: What??

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Those things he wrote? He meant them. I know that. That hurt. Cigarette? I need one. She lights a cigarette. But I accepted. Like you will.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  92.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: I am a part of his life, and I accept that you are too.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I don't accept you.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: What about Dorothy Schiff? Do you accept her? (then) Why do you think she has built that place next to Top Cottage?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: There are other cottages on that hill--

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: He asked her to. He asked her to build a cottage, so they could live close together when he retired, while he wrote those goddamn detective books he's always talking about writing.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I don't believe--.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: I read the letter.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: When was this?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) This year.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: No. (then) Why don't you leave him?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: For the same reason you won't. Daisy looks out -- into the dawn.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: It wasn’t Eleanor who ‘abandoned’ him. She caught him too.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: With you?  93.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (laughs ) No. This was -- long ago. Years and years ago. Someone else. He promised never to see her again. Swore on his knees.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Did he? See her again?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: She’s been to the White House. Maybe you've met her. Mrs. Rutherford. Daisy looks back out the window.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry that I... I misunderstood her. (then) I don't think I can 'share'-

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Oh I think you can. You can. She lights both cigarettes and hands one to Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Thank you. They smoke in silence. Then: She hands Daisy her car keys And she opens the car door.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: You decide. Pause. INT. STUDY. NIGHT. Franklin alone; a half-played game of solitaire on his de in front of him. He fiddles with the cards in his hand, h mind elsewhere; he looks at the played cards, begins to s them up to start another game. INT. HALLWAY / LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. A dishevelled Daisy walks down the hallway at Springwood. Franklin’s Mother sits outside of Franklin's study, as if guarding it. She sees Daisy and watches her approach.  94.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (standing) He won't go to bed. He’s waiting for you. Daisy goes into the study without knocking. INT. STUDY. NIGHT. Daisy has sat down.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Would you like a drink?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: No. He starts to pour himself one, then decides not to.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Missy and my Mother have both severely criticized me for not having invited you to the dinner tonight. I want to apologize. They both said I should not treat you that way. In the future -- it will be different. She musters all of her strength:

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Yes. Uncomfortable, Franklin picks up his magnifying glass.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I think I showed you these when you first came to visit me, Daisy. But you probably don't remember. Daisy says nothing. Then:

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I remember.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: From Africa. Aren't they beautiful? Can you see from there? Daisy is standing at a distance.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I can.  95. She can’t. He turns the pages of the stamp album.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: The highest waterfall in the world. That's on this stamp. He is pointing out a stamp in his stamp book.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I really don't think you can see from way over there, Daisy. I really don't. And that -- would be terrible. Not to. That, Daisy, I believe would be an awful mistake. From which neither of us would recover...

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Do you really think that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. I do. He looks at her. No longer smiling, but beseeching.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: How do you see me?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Am I -- to you -- just stupid?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: No. No, Daisy. But I can understand how you can feel that way.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Am I -- like a whore?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (almost laughs) No, no you are not ‘like a whore.'

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Am I just 'comfortable' for you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I don't know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Am I -- a pet?  Pause. 96.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Is that what you think?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Maybe. (Pause) It isn't.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Good. Now come and sit next to me.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (yells) No, you're not getting off that easy, you son of a bitch!!

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: But that’s not what I said. Instead:

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: No. I need to go.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Daisy... This stops her at the door. She looks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth listening Daisy... Mother’s -- quite -- worried. I told her there was nothing to be worried about -- with Daisy. That you'd understand. And you'd never do anything... or cause any... Because you --. We understand each other, don’t we, Daisy? And you know that everything I’ve ever said to you was true. at him, then nods and starts to leave the study. I’d say I’m sorry -- but that wouldn’t do any good right now, would it? BEDROOM. /EXT. FRONT OF HOUSE. DAWN PRE-SUNRISE. at the window; Bertie, with the door cracked open, at the door.  97.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Someone's coming out. He hurries to the window.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Which one is she?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: The one you think looks like a governess. From Elizabeth and Bertie’s perspective we see Daisy havi just come out of the house, she now heads for her car.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I thought she was the governess. Has she stopped crying? Can you tell?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (as they watch) By the way, I understand that's a very common thing -- men and their children's governesses.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Is it? How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: So I'm told.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: She's not the governess. But she's obviously his mistress.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: She dresses like a--.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: She's not the governess, Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Men find -- some men find-- I think because they're around children, there's something quite attractive about--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (as she continues to look out the window) ) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH (cont'd) Why do you keep talking about governesses? Is there something you want to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: No. Nothing. Why? Daisy is driving away.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Well, she’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Look over there. From Elizabeth and Bertie’s perspective, we see Missy in distance on a bench.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: The secretary?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (nods ) I hadn’t seen her before. You can just make her out now. It's going to be light soon. See her?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: And she's his mistress too. According to Cameron.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: We don't need Cameron to--.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Cameron says there's another one.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Another--?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Who's married. But she's built a cottage by his? Or something.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Another mistress?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (after another look toward Missy) Good thing we changed our minds about bringing Lilibet with us.  99.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You changed your mind. I never wanted to bring Lilibet to America.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Only be-be-because you don't like Americans.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I like Americans. That’s not fair. I don’t like a lot of Americans. I like some. (then) Are you going to eat a hot dog?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: What???

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: At the picnic. Tomorrow. Today. Are you? I mean, isn't it like having say the PM over and serving him bangers and mash?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: He probably would like--.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: To a guest! If we did that he'd know we were trying to tell him something. He'd understand.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: What would he understand?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: How we felt about him.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: The PM knows how we feel about him. We like him. As if that matters.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (over this) You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I wish I did.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Bertie, I don't think your brother would eat a hot dog.  100.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (upset now) How would you know that?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Because he'd know what was meant!!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: It doesn't mean anything!!! A light knock on the door, which is still open a bit; Cam sticks his head in; he’s in his pajamas and robe.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: The walls, sir. They are quite thin.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: We know.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: One can hear--.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Everyone in this house is already awake. Bertie looks at the window, Cameron follows his look and Missy standing now, smoking.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (to Elizabeth) But to answer your question, Elizabeth, I am going to eat a hot dog, no five hot dogs, ten! I'm going to shove them into my mouth, stick two up my nostrils, two more in my ears, then walk around so people can take pictures of the King of England with hot dogs hanging out of his orifices!! Elizabeth suddenly looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (as they watch) Don't ever compare me to my brother again. Elizabeth doesn't know what to say. Cameron steps in:

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Look, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: What?  101.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: The President. EXT. FRONT OF THE HOUSE. DAWN PRE-SUNRISE. Franklin is coming out on his own. His legs are in braces he uses a cane. Missy throws down her cigarette and walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (quietly to Missy) Has she gone? Missy nods.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (quietly) What do you think she’s going to do?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (quietly) I don’t think she’1l cause you any trouble. If that’s what you’re asking. Is that what you’re asking? INT. PINK BEDROOM. DAWN. Elizabeth and Bertie at the window. Cameron peeks over th From their perspective, we watch Missy look up at the win

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: They’1l see us. Too late. Franklin, following Missy’s glance, has looked and seen them. He tries to hide his surprise and any embarrassment. From their perspective:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (putting on a good front) Hello! And good morning!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (whispers through his smile) Wave.  102.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (through her smile) I am. Both are waving now.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (shouting down) Hello! Lovely morning, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (calling down) Hello! Hello! Missy and Qualters wave now too.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Hello!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (calling up) Sleep well?!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (calling down) Oh yes. Yes, very well. Didn't we?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (calling down) We did!

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (waving) Yes!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (shouting up) Good! Me too!! (then) I thought I might have a swim... Come along? INT. DAISY’S HOUSE HALLWAY / STAIRS. DAWN. The very dishevelled Daisy, dress ripped, hair a mess, kn bloodied, passes the hallway mirror. She stops and stares at herself in the mirror -- a mess. AUNT’S VOICE Daisy is that you?  103. Daisy continues to stare into the mirror. INT. DAISY’S HOUSE, AUNT’S BEDROOM. DAWN. Daisy enters her Aunt’s dark bedroom. She can just make o her aunt sitting on her bed in her nightgown, trying to p her stockings on by herself.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Let me help. Daisy goes and kneels in front of her and helps.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT
dialogues.text: (oblivious to Daisy’s condition) You're up early.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I just woke up. Daisy rolls up the Aunt’s stockings. EXT. FRONT OF HOUSE. DAY. The door opens and Bertie, feeling quite self-conscious i his bathing suit, stands in the doorway. Franklin, in his car, smiles and waves. Bertie ‘waves.’ Steps out and immediately sees the single Marine, keeping guard on the steps. The Marine, seeing th King, immediately salutes and stands at attention. Self-consciously in his bathing suit, Bertie salutes the soldier, and tries not to hurry to the car. EXT. GATE-HOUSE. DAY. Franklin, in his bathing suit, at the wheel of his car. Bertie in his bathing suit in the passenger seat. They approach the gate house; across the drive, twenty or thir reporters/photographers, nearly all with cameras around t necks, are clustered together. He slows door to banter with the reporters:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: They feeding you all right out here? Throwing you boys, the odd bone?  104.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: We're eatin’ like kings. Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: You can thank him for that. (smiles at Bertie) They drive past, not a photo has been taken:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (driving) I made them all agree -- no pictures in our bathing suits. (looks down at Bertie’s legs) Though you don’t look so bad. Maybe you should get your picture taken like that... As they drive off:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: And get the women’s vote. But that’s right -- you don’t vote for king. EXT. VAL KILL SWIMMING POOL. DAY. The King and the President alone together in the pool; swimming past each other, curling left, then right, playi and enjoying the freedom, the peace, the water, and the company. EXT. ROAD TO TOP COTTAGE. DAY. Franklin, cigarette in mouth, is at the wheel of his car, climbing up the steep and bumpy hill. Bertie in the back. Elizabeth, in the front seat, bounces around, looking sic her stomach. A line of soldiers has formed along the edge of the woods one side of the dirt road; as the car passes, the soldier salute. The King, bouncing in the backseat, tries to wave back.  105. EXT. TOP COTTAGE. DAY. The picnic. Crowds of people milling around -- locals, government officials, friends -- all with glasses in hand greeting each -- checking out who else has been invited. women in fancy summer hats. A makeshift stage has been bu off of the porch for the entertainment. Tables are covered in dishes: Virginia ham, cold turkey, sausages, salads, rolls. A table of beer. Daisy has brought her Aunt lemonade and a drink for herse They are at a table on the periphery.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT
dialogues.text: What are you drinking?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (hesitates, then) It’s a beer, Aunt Sophie. I like it. Daisy sits. As she looks off across the crowd, she instinctively takes a cigarette out of her pocket, and st to light it. The Aunt is amazed.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT
dialogues.text: When did you start to do that?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Do what? Suddenly some word starts to spread through the crowd, an everyone starts to head toward the driveway -- the Royals coming. Aunt stands to follow, but Daisy just sits, lost in her thoughts, smoking. EXT. TOP COTTAGE. DAY. Cameron is the first to reach Roosevelt’s car; he helps Elizabeth out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (under her breath to Cameron) ) I'm not driving with him again.  106. EXT. TOP COTTAGE. DAY. Eleanor has taken Bertie’s arm, and leads the King and Qu into the waiting and eager crowd for a few important introductions. Women immediately begin to curtsey. EXT. TOP COTTAGE. DAY. Franklin is carried around the crowd to the main table on porch. All of the guests pretend not to see this. EXT. TOP COTTAGE. DAY. Bertie has a small movie camera, and he takes a panoramic shot of the house and countryside -- as he pans, guests d so as not to obstruct his view. The King gestures for the guests to wave to him. They wave. He films. He finishes the shot; winds the camera; and then with Elizabeth at his side, he sees the grill -- and the cooki hot dogs. After a look at Elizabeth, he begins to film the hot dogs EXT. TOP COTTAGE. DAY. Missy and Qualters stand at the lemonade table, and watch crowd watch Bertie film the hot dogs and the guests. Qualters nudges Missy and nods. He’s just noticed Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: She's here.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (watching Daisy) Good for her. Missy takes the glass and heads toward Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: What are you doing? EXT. TOP COTTAGE. DAY. Daisy and her Aunt sit at the distant table, now full of unimportant guests who have been relegated to the far rea of the party.  107. The Aunt, because of the crowds and the distance, is havi hard time seeing. Daisy sits, seemingly completely disinterested. Missy works her way through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Mind if I join you? (quietly) I’m so pleased you came.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I promised my Aunt. EXT. TOP COTTAGE. DAY. An Aide helps Franklin into one of the chairs. No one is taking pictures. Bertie sits in the other chair. Everyone waits for the wheelchair to be pushed out of view and the suddenly all take photographs of the King and Franklin po together. EXT. TOP COTTAGE DAY. With the photographers’ flash bulbs going off behind him, a crowd laughing at Franklin and Bertie’s show of playfulness, Qualters comes to Daisy, Missy and the Aunt’ table.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (feigning surprise) Tommy, looks who’s here.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: Daisy, would you come with me? He tries to take her arm.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (stopping him) Tommy, she has every right to be here.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: He wants her sitting with him. He tries to take her arm again.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I’m not doing that.  108.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT
dialogues.text: Who wants you sitting with him?

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: The President, ma’am. Daisy, please.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to. No.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT
dialogues.text: Daisy, please. Where are your manners? (standing) Let’s sit up with the President.

dialogues.speaker: QUALTERS
dialogues.text: Just Daisy, ma’am. He just wants her. (to Daisy) Please. Daisy looks to Missy. Who nods. The photos are over and there is a big cheer. EXT. TOP COTTAGE. DAY. Daisy is led to the head table -- nearly everyone is now curious and watching. Franklin and Bertie are laughing together. As Daisy approaches -- there’s that big Franklin smile:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: What were you doing way over there, Daisy? The special guests are here on the porch. You should be here. He turns to the King.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: You've met Miss Daisy Suckley, haven't you, your Majesty?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I’ve had the pleasure. Daisy does a faint curtsey. Bertie and Elizabeth share a quick look. The guests are all rubber-necking to see what is happenin the porch.  109.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: She's going to join us. Aren’t you, Daisy? Tommy get her a chair. (introducing Daisy to the Queen) And her Majesty. A bigger curtsey for the Queen as Qualters brings a chair Daisy. She will sit next to Franklin. Eleanor -- understanding -- scoots over to make room for Daisy’s chair.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Daisy, please, sit down. She hesitates. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Please, Daisy. She just stares at him. Daisy looks to Eleanor, then at Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Would you like some beer? Daisy hesitates, nods. And sits.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Franklin, pour Daisy some beer. Franklin smiles, gives Eleanor a look of ‘thank you’ and pours beer into Daisy’s glass. As the Royals try not to watch. EXT. TOP COTTAGE. DAY. A medley of the entertainment: Ish-Ti-Opi, the Indian Baritone sings The Zuni Blanket Wo Song. The King and Queen are attentive. He sings The Traditional Potato Song. Franklin looks to Daisy, and smiles at her; she attempts to ignore this and him, and watch the Indian performer instead.  110. EXT. TOP COTTAGE. DAY. Bertie stands and with his movie camera films Princess Te performing the Indian Corn Ceremony. As he films with one hand, he loosens his tie with the other. EXT. TOP COTTAGE DAY. Princess Te Ata finishes demonstrating Indian Sign Langua The King, now with his tie off, and Queen politely applau EXT. TOP COTTAGE DAY. Ish-Ti-Opi now in full Indian Head Dress doing the Sun Ri Call as Franklin leans over Daisy to Eleanor:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (Half whisper) How much more of this is there? Ish-Ti-Opi finishes to polite applause. He turns to the t tom player and begins The Canoe Song. Franklin notices th Queen’s eyes beginning to droop; it has been a long day.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (applauds and shouts out) Thank you, Indian Baritone! Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (applauding, under her breath, across Daisy) He wasn't finished. Daisy, still expressionless, looks Eleanor, then to Frank for his response.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (smiling) Oh. I thought he was. Then Daisy looks to Eleanor for her response; she is righ the middle of the Husband/Wife spat. The Queen is startled awake by the applause. Elizabeth an Bertie applaud.  111. EXT. TOP COTTAGE DAY. At the head table, Thomas whispers in Franklin's ear, he nods. Franklin leans over and touches Bertie on the arm t gets his attention:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Your Majesty... Thomas brings over a platter of hot dogs in buns. He hold the tray out for the King. Word of this spreads fast through the crowd, and suddenly everyone watching this, some people get up and stand so t can see better. Missy helps the Aunt get up and watch. Daisy has the best view, right next to Franklin. She watc though still without showing any enthusiasm. Silence. Franklin takes the platter from Thomas and holds it out t the King. Would you like -- a hot dog? The Queen looks away. Everyone else is looking at the Kin

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Mr. President, I very much would like a hot dog. What he has just said is passed along through the crowd. The King takes a hot dog in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Do you take mustard?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I take whatever you think I should take with my hot dog.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Allow us then to put a bit of mustard on for you. Smiling, Franklin nods to Daisy to pick up the mustard po that is already on the table. Daisy doesn’t know what to Eleanor starts to pick it up, but Franklin shakes his hea He wants Daisy to do this.  112. Eleanor hands Daisy the mustard pot. Suddenly with all eyes watching, a nervous Daisy carefull takes the mustard and holds it out, as if it were a crown Then Franklin hands her a knife.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Show him how we put it on, Daisy. Daisy nervously takes the knife and gently and very very carefully spreads mustard on the King’s hot dog. Every one in the crowd watches her every move. The Aunt stands now, looking so proud, Missy stands watching at her side, keenly interested. When Daisy has finished putting on the mustard, she caref sets down the knife.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (to Daisy) You are too kind. Daisy is embarrassed by the attention. Then Bertie raises the hot dog to his mouth -- and bites it. Suddenly the crowd of guests burst into cheers and applause. Bertie is confused.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (over this, to Franklin) Why are they applauding? What's this about? Franklin is smiling, patting the King on the back; Daisy caught in the middle of all this cheering. She’s embarras

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: And like that -- we felt America and England were back on the road to being very good friends. At least, I’m told that’s how some people took it. A very happy crowd of Americans still applauding.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: It made me wonder -- maybe the hot dogs hadn’t been Eleanor’s idea after all.  129 113. Franklin watches Bertie bask in the applause.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: When he left for England later that day, the King sent back a telegram, in which he wrote that our two nations had now ‘forged’ -- and these are his words: ‘a special relationship.’ Smiling, Bertie shouts out:

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I'll have another!! Another burst of exuberant cheers. EXT. DAISY’S HOUSE. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: The next day, he sent a car. A car is parked in front of Daisy’s house.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: But I said I was too ill to take a drive. A driver stands on the porch talking to the Aunt who hold open the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: I was ill the next day. And the next. And the next day after that. He turns and walks back across the porch and to his car. door slams. EXT. DAISY’S HOUSE. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: A week after the Royals’ visit to Hyde Park, the President came in person to my house. Franklin, at the wheel of his car, drives up to Daisy’s 1 house. Daisy’s Aunt is on the porch, having her morning cup of coffee, when suddenly she sees who is arriving. She stand knocks over the little wicker table, starts to pick it up then doesn’t bother and hurries inside.  114.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: I had been waiting. After a moment, Daisy hesitantly comes out of her house. looks at Franklin. EXT. HARDWARE SHOP. DAY. Franklin, smoking, with Daisy next to him in his car, as slowly drives through the village of Hyde Park.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: He drove us by the plumbing shop where his mother had returned the toilet seat she had ordered for the Royal Visit, without paying for it. The car stops outside the hardware shop. There is a toile and a sign: “THE KING AND QUEEN OF ENGLAND SAT HERE.” He starts to laugh, and she can’t help but smile and warm little to him. As she looks up at him: DAISY’S VOICE He tried to make me laugh. And he was good at that. He was after all a politician.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Mother wants to pay him now. But he says it’s really been good for business. He smiles at her. DAISY VO. He hoped I would forgive him. But I was damned if I was going to tell him that I already had. EXT./INT. MISSY’S CAR AT DAISY’S HOUSE. DAY. Daisy comes out of her house, pulling on her glove, holdi her hat. She slides into the passenger seat of Missy’s ca Missy, in the driver's seat, leans over and they give eac other a hug.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: Occasionally now, Missy would come and fetch me when she felt --.  115. Daisy looks into the rearview mirror and starts to puts o her hat.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: I think he could really use -- your company tonight. Missy watches as Daisy continues to put on her hat, tryin get it right. Missy looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Let him wait. (she smiles) Missy begins to help fix Daisy's hair, around the hat. Da adjusts her hair and hat just so, with Missy’s help and approval. INT. LIVING ROOM. EVENING.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: I learned, as we got to know each other better, of Missy's bouts with her 'blackness.' Franklin, Missy, Daisy and Qualters around a card table playing bridge; Missy and Daisy sit across from each othe they are partners. Missy takes a trick, and smiles at her partner.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: And of her 'dark days.' And suicide attempts. She takes another trick and the Girls are having a very g time beating the Boys, who show no expression -- they don like losing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papers and files are being packed up by Aides and Missy, is on her knees in the middle of the room, sorting things

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: When Missy fell terribly ill. He paid for everything. Daisy sits alone in a corner pretending to read a book, b every now and then looking at Missy:  116.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: He even changed his will -- giving her half -- should she outlive him. But to the surprise of nearly everyone -- he did not visit her once in the hospital. I asked him why. Franklin wheels himself into the study, in his chair, and heads for his desk. His mind on other things. Daisy just watches him.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: It's a terrible fault of mine, he said. I find it too painful to be around illness. INT. LIVING ROOM/STUDY. DAY. 1942. Everything is being packed up; phone lines rolled up; furniture returned to its proper places. Daisy watches fr the doorway. She turns and heads through the room, trying to stay out the way of the moving. As she reaches the study, the door opens and Mother comes out; looking suspicious. Daisy smiles politely at Mother goes in.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (whispers) Close the door, Daisy. She closes the door. And Franklin suddenly lifts a hat up his desk and there, under it -- is a drink. Others in the room, bring out the drinks they’d hidden fr Mother -- from a plant, a bookcase, under their jacket. A laugh -- a wonderful camaraderie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Someone pour Daisy a drink! Missy pours a glass and gives it to her. The two share a -- a shared understanding. And the others, the men go bac packing up the study. Daisy looks around, smiling -- she miss this.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: I grew close not only to Missy but to all of Franklin’s boys. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAISY VO (cont'd) They seemed to accept me, no questions asked. And no more promised were made so none could be broken. EXT. ENTRYWAY OF HOUSE / DRIVEWAY. DAY. 1942. The caravan of official cars are lined up for the exodus to Washington. Daisy stands at a distance and watches Franklin be carrie his car.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: Though he found he could now visit home -- Hyde Park -- less and less. There were elections. Then the war. Always so many things... A line of photographers patiently waits until he is in; a then -- he turns to them, an Aide nods to the photographe Franklin smiles and the flashbulbs pop like fourth of Jul They continue to pop -- and the newsreel cameras buzz -- caravan heads off down the drive. A few townspeople stand clusters and wave. Daisy slowly heads off across the field, alone, watching caravan snake its way down the long tree-lined driveway t the road.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: He always seemed confident that I'd be here waiting... She watches the cars.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY VO
dialogues.text: And oh how I resented that... As the caravan reaches the road and turns; Daisy suddenly begins to runs toward it, faster and faster; and she star to wave as she runs. She continues to run and wave until the cars, the caravan and Franklin are out of sight. And stops and stares off toward where he has disappeared. CAPTIONS: FDR eventually kept his promise and by 1942 Bri and the United States were fighting shoulder to shoulder. When Daisy died in her hundredth year, a box of letters a diaries was found under her bed.  118. Her special relationship with the President was, finally, longer just their secret.
